She is currently remodeling a space in her house to sell natural medicines and drinks. For the last year, she has also been selling beauty products from house to house, visiting her friends and neighbors to offer merchandise from catalogs as well as what she has in stock.

The thing that Evelyn likes most about her work is the contact with her customers, with whom she shares ideas. She makes many friends since she provides great customer service and is very good-humored. On the other hand, she thinks that her business is profitable because she works with a cosmetic brand that is very well-known and her customers do not hesitate in making orders.

In the future, Evelyn would like to have a mini-market that sells a variety of products to her neighbors and other customers.

This is her first loan with Microfinanzas Prisma, and she has noticed that her friends in her communal bank are very trustworthy and responsible. They are also very enthusiastic about the work they have begun doing towards improving their respective businesses. Evelyn will use the money from this loan to purchase more beauty products, natural medicines, and beverages, and thereby increase her income.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Petrona Isabel

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Managua, la señora Petrona Isabel L. se ha destacado por ser trabajadora del hogar y por velar siempre por el sustento a su casa de habitación.

Ella atraviesa la necesidad de inverter en el mejoramiento de su vivienda debido a que los años han transcurrido y cada día su vivienda se ha ido dañando y por tal razón ella solicita un crédito para adquirir los materiales de construcción para iniciar la obra y así brindarle un techo digno donde habitar a su familia compuesta por su pequeño hijo en edad escolar.
texts.en:
Petrona Isabel L. lives in Managua, where is is known to be a very hardworking homemaker, ever watchful of the maintenance of her home.

However, she has reached a point when she must invest in improvements to her house, which has gotten damaged over the years. For this reason, she is asking for a loan to purchase construction materials to begin making repairs so that she can provide an adequate home for her family, which includes her young school-aged son.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials

loans.name: Lucia Otilia

texts.en:
Every day, Senora Lucia P. fills her large basket and sells different types of clothing in a little building, a “caseta”, on the edge of the street. Twice a month, Lucia goes to Managua, the capital of Nicaragua, to buy clothing for her store. She also buys some things from suppliers who stop by her store. She is going to use her loan to buy clothing for men, women, and children. Before she had a permanent location, Lucia carried her goods around the streets of Leon to sell them.

Lucia has had nine loans with Kiva partner, CEPRODEL. The loans have improved her quality of life and also improved her business in small increments. Lucia is married with three school-aged children.

loans.use: To buy clothing for men, women, and children

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: María De Jesús

texts.es: En el departamento de Managua, la señora María de Jesús Jarquín se dedica a la venta de ropa ambulantemente siendo ofrecida en diferentes partes de la capital donde ella se traslada de un lado para otro ofreciendo la ropa. Ella actualmente atraviesa la situación de que se le ha agotado la mercadería  y es por este motivo que ella solicita un crédito con el único fin de invertir el dinero en la compra de la mercadería como es ropa para continuar ofreciéndola ambulantemente y así mejorar las condiciones de su negocio.
texts.en:
María de Jesús Jarquín lives in Mangua and is a street vendor who travels all around the city selling clothing. She has reached a point where she has run out of merchandise and so she is requesting a loan with the sole purpose of investing the money in the purchase of merchandise. In this way she will be able to continue selling clothing and improve the condition of her business.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: María José

texts.es:
En Managua, capital de Nicaragua, la señora María C. se esfuerza a diario para mejorar las condiciones de su negocio el cual consiste en la venta de cosméticos siendo ofrecidos por ella en vitrinas y son varios los clientes que le visitan para comprar los cosméticos. También ella se destaca en la venta de comestibles como hot dogs los que son preparados por ella misma.

Actualmente solicita el crédito para invertirlo a lo inmediato en la compra de los cosméticos y también en la compra de la materia prima para elaborar los comestibles y así mejorar sus ingresos.
texts.en:
In Managua, the capital of Nicaragua, Sra. María C. strives daily to improve the condition of her business selling cosmetics. Her products are presented in display cases as many customers pass through to buy her merchandise. In addition, María sells snacks, such as hot dogs, that she prepares herself.

She is currently requesting a loan to purchase cosmetics and also ingredients for preparing snacks so that she can improve her income.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Puchase cosmetics & ingredients for preparing snacks

loans.name: Neri Verónica

texts.es:
Neri M. es una dama muy trabajadora que se dedica a la venta de verduras en el mercado Israel Lewites de la ciudad de Managua quien desde muy temprano se esfuerza por llevar a cabo su tarea de venta de las verduras donde es visitada por los clientes en el mercado.

A pesar que ella no posee un local eficiente para llevar a cabo su actividad, ha buscado la manera de como vender más para así continuar llevando el sustento a su hogar. Es por este motivo que solocita un crédito para la compra de las verduras como lo son tomates, papas, chiltomas, chayotes y otros. Con este crédito se beneficia grandemente en su actividad.
texts.en:
Neri M. is a hardworking woman who sells vegetables at the Israel Lewites Market in the city of Managua. She begins her day very early so that she can go about selling vegetables to all of her customers who visit the market.

Despite not having an efficient location to carry out her business, she has found ways to sell more produce and continue sustaining her household. For this reason, she is requesting a loan to purchase vegetables such as tomatoes, potatoes, bell peppers, chayote, etc. Her business will greatly benefit from this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchae vegetables

loans.name: Miriam Del Carmen

texts.es:
Miriam R. se dedica a la actividad de venta de ropa en el departamento de Managua donde ofrece ropa para damas, caballeros y niños. Ella se ha destacado por ser una excelente trabajadora y ha logrado llevar el sustento a su hogar de habitación habiendo beneficiado a su pequeño hijo en edad escolar.

La razón por la que ha solicitado el crédito es para invertirlo en la compra de la ropa ya que se le ha agotado y requiere invertir a lo inmediato para obtener las utilidades y seguir manteniendo su núcleo familiar.
texts.en:
Miriam R. sells clothing for men, women, and children in the department of Managua. She is known as an excellent worker who manages to maintain her household. Miriam has a young son who is in school.

She is requesting a loan to buy more clothing since she has exhausted all of her funds and needs to invest in her business so that she can generate immediate profits and continue supporting her family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her business

loans.name: Marlon Enrique

texts.es: El señor Marlon R. de 31 años de edad, se dedica ala venta de comida, junto con su esposa que es la cocinera llevan dos años en las ventas, cuando inicio lo hizo con fondos propios de su trabajo como albañil, cocinan en peroles grandes sopa, comida sólida y la venden a las pesonas que trabajan en proyectos de construcción y dan crédito ala quincena por que es dinero fijo, su esposa procreo  dos hijos de 8 y 12 años de edad, los cuales cursan la primaria y sus deseos es poder dar una buena educación a su niños ya que ellos no terminaron su educación por falta de pocos recursos de economía de sus padres vive en el barrio Sierrita de Santo Domingo y con este préstamo va a comprar cazuela grande para preparar los alimentos y compraran granos básicos, carnes, verduras y frutas para hacer los refrescos.a futuro desea poner un bajarete en donde cocina ya que es en un fogon en el patio y en los dias de inviernos se le dificulta mucho, tambien  poder captar clientes nuevos, vender mas para mejorar en la economía ya que uno de los problemas es que abecés retrasan el pago debido a que no les han pagado por falta de fondo den la institución, por la crisis económica que pasa el país. Da las gracias Afodenic por el financiamiento que ha dado el cual espera corresponder en tiempo y forma.
texts.en:
Marlon R. is 31. He and his wife, the cook, have been selling food for two years. He started with his own funds from his work as a bricklayer. They cook soups in big kettles and solid food, which they sell to the people working on construction projects. They give their customers credit until payday because it is stable income. They have two children, eight and twelve. The children are in elementary school. Their wish is to be able to give their children a good education. They did not finish their education because of their parents’ lack of economic resources. He lives in the Sierrita de Santo Domingo neighborhood. With this loan he will buy a large pan to prepare the food. They will also buy basic grains, meats, vegetables, and fruits to make the refreshments. In the future, he wants to set up a covered patio where they can cook. Now they cook on a burner on the patio, and this is difficult on winter days. Also, they would like to be able to get new customers and to sell more to improve their income. One of the problems they have is that sometimes their customers do not pay them because their customers have not received their pay. This is due to the lack of funds in the economic crisis that is occurring in the country. He is grateful to Afodenic for the loan he was given. He expects to pay it back on time and in the agreed upon manner.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy kitchen utensils and food to prepare

loans.name: María Teresa

texts.es:
La señora María Teresa M. se dedica a su actividad de venta de verduras en el departamento de Managua donde a diario ella ofrece las verduras y son varios los clientes que le visitan para obtener los perecederos. Ella cuenta con una mesa de madera donde coloca tales productos y los ofrece.

La necesidad que la señora María Teresa atraviesa es que requiere de un crédito para invertirlo en la compra de las verduras como cebollas, chayotes, ajo, naranjas, entre otros, y por tal motivo es que espera confiadamente para así mejorar las condiciones de la actividad y satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes que  a diario le visitan para adquirir los perecederos.
texts.en:
Mrs. María Teresa M. sells vegetables in the department of Managua where she offers them daily to a variety of customers who visit her for perishables. She sells her products from the wood table where she displays them.

The needs of Mrs. María Teresa require a loan so she can invest in the purchase of vegetables like onions, chayotes (vegetable pears), garlic, and oranges, among other things. For this reason, she optimistically hopes she will be able to improve the quality of her business and satisfy the needs of her customers who visit her daily to purchase perishables.

Translated from Spanish by Lauren Jackson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase vegetables

loans.name: Rosa Argentina

texts.en:
Rosa B. sells sodas, candies, purified water, and prepaid cell phone minutes for both of Nicaragua’s main cell phone providers, Moviestar and Claro. She sells her goods across from the bus stop that services the Leon to Managua express buses. She also makes papitas mexicanas, Mexican-style chicken wings, in her kitchen. She is going to use this loan to buy sodas, water and ingredients for the papitas.

Rosa has been in this business for 41 years. Initially, she sold sodas while walking around on the street. She started her business using personal savings. Now her store is open air but underneath a small roof. She says loans have helped her business grow incrementally. They have also helped her make many improvements to her house which has improved her quality of life. Rosa is single with one child.

loans.use: To buys sodas, water and ingredients for chicken wings

loans.name: Lino Jose

texts.es: El joven Lino José Gutiérrez, tiene la edad de 25 años, habita en el barrio A gusto Farría, ubicado en Masaya , junto a su esposa la cual trabaja como comerciante para apoyarle con los gastos del hogar , ellos tienen un hijos de dos añitos , los planes futuros hacia su familia es poder construir su vivienda ya que actualmente habitan en la casa de su suegra y se le hace muy difícil tener una privacidad con su familia , don Lino desde hace tres años trabaja en reparación y venta de bicicletas , el inicio con ahorro de su esposa y la liquidación de su anterior trabajo , un año después agradece el apoyo de afodenic por la buena aprobación de su primer crédito el cual invirtió en comprar de diferentes repuesto y logro pagarlo en tiempo y forma , ahora con este segundo quiere repuesto para motocicletas y ofrecer un mejor servicio a sus clientes . En un futuro quiere comprar un tramo en el mercado y poder trabajar desde allí y obtener más ganancias y construir su vivienda ya que los materiales de construcción están caros y tiene que ir poco a poco para poder darle a su familia una vivienda propia y digna.
texts.en:
Lino José Gutiérrez, 25, lives in the Agusto Farría neighborhood, which is in Masaya. His wife works as a shopkeeper to help meet household expenses; they have a two-year-old son. His future plans for his family is to be able to build their own home since they currently share space in his mother-in-law's house and it is very difficult to have any privacy for his family. For the past three years, Lino has worked as a bicycle sales- and repairman. He started his business using his wife's savings and his severance pay from his former job. A year later, he is grateful to Afodenic for having approved his first loan which he used to buy various replacement parts. He managed to repay in a timely fashion. Now, he would like this second loan to buy motorcycle replacement parts to offer his customers better service. In the future, he would like to buy a space in the market so that he can work from there and earn higher profits to build his house since building materials are very expensive and he must proceed little by little to give his family their own, suitable housing.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy motorcycle replacement parts to improve customer service.

loans.name: Oscar Augusto

texts.es: El señor Oscar Agusto M. García, tiene la edad de 41 años, habita en el barrio Cobilaco, ubicado en La Concepción Masaya, junto a su esposa la cual trabaja en lavado y planchado para apoyarle con los gastos del pago de agua, luz y alimentos que no alcanzan en la quincena, ellos tienen tres hijos ya todos independientes, una de las hijas habita con ellos actualmente ya que es madre soltera, los planes hacia su familia es poder ayudar a su hija para que realice su vivienda , don Oscar desde hace veinte años se dedica a los trabajos agrícolas gracias a los esfuerzos de su esposa y los suyos , la mayor afectación que se le presenta en el cultivo es las cenizas del volcán  ya que en ocasiones a quemado la producción ; agradece a la institución por la buena aprobación de su préstamo el cual lo va a invertir en fertilizantes e insumos para sacar un buena cosecha y vender a buen precio en el M. y poder cubrir sus gastos personales como pagar en tiempos su credito.
texts.en:
Oscar Agusto M. García, 41, lives in the Cobilaco neighborhood, which is in La Concepción Masaya. His wife works taking in washing and ironing to help him with household expenses like water, electricity and food since his earnings are not sufficient. They have three children, all of whom are independent. One of their daughters currently lives with them since she is a single mother. Future plans for his family is to help his daughter get her own house. For the past 20 years, Oscar has worked as a farmer thanks to his wife's and family's support. The greatest difficulty he has to face with his crops is the damage done to them by the ashes from the volcano since they tend to burn the crops. He is grateful to the institution for approving his loan which he plans to use to buy raw materials and fertilizers so that he can get a better crop yield and sell at better market prices so that he can cover his personal expenses as well as repay his loan in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials and fertilizers for his crops.

loans.name: Johanna Lucia

texts.es: La joven Johanna Lucia García , tiene la edad de 24 años, habita en el barrio San Juan, junto a su esposo el cual trabaja como guarda de seguridad en una empresa privada , para apoyarle con los gastos del hogar , ellos tienen dos hijos varones de diez y un bebé de tres meses de nacido , doña Johana desde hace seis años se dedica a los trabajos agrícola y tiene el apoyo de su suegra , los planes hacia un futuro es mejorar la vivienda ya que le quiere cambiar el techo , por que en tiempo de invierno el agua le afecta ya que tienes mucho orificios por ser muy viejo.  Agradece a Afodenic por la buena aprobación de su sexto crédito, el cual lo va a invertir en insumos agrícolas, para mejorar la producción.
texts.en:
Johanna Lucia García, 24, lives in the San Juan neighborhood with her husband, who works as a security guard in a private company to help her with household expenses. They have two sons, a 10-year-old and a three-month-old newborn. Johana has been a farmer for the past 6 years and she counts on her mother-in-law's support. Her plan for the future is to improve her house because she needs to replace the roof which is heavily damaged and has many holes which in the Winter allow water to come in and do a lot of damage. She is grateful to Afodenic for approving her 6th loan which she will use to buy raw materials to improve her crop yields.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials and fertilizers for her crops.

loans.name: Maria Isabel

texts.es:
La señora MARIA ISABEL L. F., tiene  47 años, vive en el distrito de Las Delicias, provincia de Trujillo, departamento La Libertad – Perú. La socia pertenece al Banco Comunal SIEMPRE UNIDAS. Ella presenta estudios  superiores de Auxiliar en educación, pero no pudo ejercer porque se caso a los 18 años al finalizar su carrera y tuvo que dedicarse al hogar y a  la crianza de sus hijos. La socia tiene 3 hijos pero solo 1 depende económicamente de ella porque se encuentra estudiando en la universidad.
Maria s e dedica a la preparación y venta de menús (alimentos) y platos criollos como: arroz con pato, pato guisado, cabrito, cebiches, caldos, etc. en el restaurante que tiene en su casa. Con su primer crédito de 300.00 nuevos soles compró mesas y vajilla para su restaurante y con su próximo crédito de 1,000 nuevos soles comprará arroz, menestras, aceite, fideos, papas, etc. para preparar los menús que venderá en el restaurante de su casa.
Ella sueña con remodelar y ampliar su local por lo cual esta ahorrando y así lograr mejorar su local.
texts.en:
. MARIA ISABEL L. F., 47, lives in the Las Delicias district, Trujillo province, La Libertad department, Perú. She is a member of the SIEMPRE UNIDAS (ALWAYS UNITED) communal bank. She studied to be a Teacher's Aide but has not been able to work in this profession because when she finished her studies she got married and had to focus on her home and on raising her three children, only one of whom is still dependent on her economically since she is a university student. Maria prepares and sells meals typical of the region like: rice with duck, roasted duck, kid, cebiche (raw fish marinated in lemon juice), soups, etc. in her home-based restaurant. With her first 300 new sol loan she bought tables and crockery for her restaurant and with her next 1000 sol loan she will buy rice, vegetables, oil, pastas, potatoes, etc. to use in preparing the meals that she will prepare and sell. She dreams with remodeling and enlarging her restaurant for which she is saving money hoping thereby to improve her locale.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, vegetables, oil, pasta, potatoes, etc. to prepare the meals she sells in her home restaurant.

loans.name: Janeth Erlinda

texts.es:
La señora JANETH ERLINDA C. C. , tiene  41 años, vive en el distrito de Las Delicias, provincia de Trujillo, departamento La Libertad – Perú. La socia pertenece al Banco Comunal SIEMPRE UNIDAS. Ella presenta estudios  superiores de enfermería técnica, pero no pudo ejercer porque al finalizar su ultimo ciclo su madre se enfermo gravemente y después falleció y no pudo obtener su titulo por motivos económicos ella empezó a trabajar como vendedora de ropa. Ella tiene 3 hijas pequeñas en edad escolar quienes dependen  económicamente de ella por ese motivo ella se dedica a la venta de pollo y gas en el mercado cercano a su casa en compañía de su esposo.
Con su primer crédito de 300.00 nuevos soles compro gas al por mayor para empezar a vender.
Con este crédito de 300.00 nuevos soles comprará pollos  para vender en el mercado y así obtener dinero para cubrir las necesidades de sus hijas.
Janeth sueña con aumentar sus vetas y poder llegar a tener su tienda de productos alimenticios para así poder obtener mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
JANETH ERLINDA C. C. , 41, lives in the Las Delicias district, Trujillo province, La Libertad department, Perú. She is a member of the SIEMPRE UNIDAS (ALWAYS UNITED) communal bank. She studied to be a technical nurse but was unable to work in her profession because during her last school term her mother became gravely ill and subsequently passed away precluding her finishing her studies and graduating. Economic necessity pushed her into clothing sales. She has three young school-age daughters who depend upon her economically. For this reason, she, together with her husband, sells gas and chickens in the local market near her home. With her first 300 sol loan she bought gas at wholesale to begin her sales. With this 300 new sol loan she will buy chickens to sell in the market thereby earning profits sufficient to cover her daughters' needs. Janeth dreams with increasing her sales enough to have her own grocery store to earn still better profits.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy wholesale chickens.

loans.name: Jessica Arazeli

texts.es:
Jessica tiene 22 años de edad, es soltera, es la segunda de tres hermanos y vive junto a sus padres y a su hermano menor en la ciudad de Lambayeque, ubicada a 15 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Desde hace cinco años ella trabaja vendiendo carne de pollo en un puesto del mercado de la ciudad de Lambayeque; su madre vende huevos en el mismo puesto. Jessica nos cuenta que empezó a trabajar allí ayudando a su madre. Mas adelante pudo instalar con sus ahorros su negocio de venta de pollo y desde entonces ha trabajado, sustentado sus gastos y apoyado a la economía de su familia con las ganancias percibidas de esta actividad.

Ella planea ampliar su negocio, por este motivo se encuentra solicitando por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que piensa utilizar en la compra de más pollo para seguir ofreciéndoselo a sus clientes y lograr su objetivo.

Su más grande anhelo es llegar a ser profesora, la especialidad que planea estudiar es Educación Inicial. Ella es muy conocida y estimada por sus compañeros del mercado.
texts.en:
Jessica is 22, single, the second of three in her family. She lives with her parents and her youngest brother in the city of Lambayeque, located 15 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. For the past five years she has worked selling chicken in a stand in the market of the city of Lambayeque. Her mother sells eggs in the same stand. Jessica tells us that she began to work there to help her mother. Later on she was able to start the chicken sales with her savings and since then she has worked, paying her expenses and supporting her family with the profits from this work. She plans to expand the business. This is why she is applying for the first time to Edpyme Alternativa for a loan of 1000 new soles ($350) that she plans to use to buy more chickens for sale to her customers and to succeed with her goal. Her great dream is to be a teacher and she plans to study Primary Education. She is well-known and respected by her friends at the market.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy chickens to expand her business

loans.name: Sixta Yolanda

texts.es:
Sixta es una madre de familia de 46 años de edad, vive junto a su esposo y tiene 6 hijos. Actualmente vive con sus dos últimos hijos, uno se encuentra estudiando aún y otro vive con ellos todavía porque es una persona especial. Todos residen en el anexo La Piedra, perteneciente al caserío Punto Cuatro, distrito de Mochumí, ubicado a 30 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Su esposo, como la mayoría de hombres de la zona, se dedica a la agricultura; pero esta actividad no genera los ingresos que necesitan para solventar la economía del hogar. Por este motivo ella tiene un negocio de preparación y venta de chicha de jora (bebida tipica hecha a base de maíz) el cual viene manejando desde hace más de 20 años. Además también teje fajas (prenda de vestir adicional utilizada por los agricultores para obtener mayor comodidad al momento de efectuar trabajo pesado).

Con estas dos actividades ella apoya a la economía de su hogar; dos veces por semana prepara la chicha y la vende a los pobladores de la zona. Además los domingos va hacia el mercado de Mochumí para vender las fajas que ha tejido durante la semana. Su tiempo diario trancurre entre el tejido de sus fajas, la preparación y venta de chicha y el cuidado de su hijo especial que tiene 15 años de edad.

Ella está solicitando por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que piensa utilizar en la compra de los insumos necesarios para elaborar la chicha de jora (maíz, azúcar, leña) así como hilos para utilizarlos en la confección de fajas.

Sixta es una madre responsable y entregada a su familia. Su más grande anhelo es poder brindarle a su hijo menor una educación de calidad y también mejorar la calidad de vida de su hijo especial para que se siga sintiendo querido y estimado por las personas que lo rodean. En la fotografía ella se encuentra preparando la chicha de jora.
texts.en:
Sixta is a 46-year-old mother of 6 children who lives together with her husband. Currently, she lives with her 2 youngest sons, one of whom is still studying and another that lives with them because he has special needs. They all reside in the annex La Piedra, belonging to the farmhouse Punto Cuatro, in the district of Mochumi, which is located 30 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. Her husband, like the majority of the men from the region, works in agriculture. However, this activity does not generate the income that they need to take care of their home expenses. For this reason, she has a business that prepares and sells chicha de jora (a common drink made from corn), which she has been managing for more than 20 years. Additionally, she knits girdles, which are used by the farmers in order to obtain greater comfort while carrying out heavy work. With these two activities, she helps with the expenses in her home. Two times a week she prepares the chicha, and she sells it to the inhabitants in the area. Also, on Sundays she goes to the market in Mochumi to sell the girdles that she has knitted during the week. Her daily time is split between knitting girdles, preparing and selling chicha, and caring for her special son who is 15 years old. She is requesting for the first time from Edpyme Alternativa a credit of 1,000 nuevos soles, which she plans to use in the purchase of necessary items for making chicha de jora (corn, sugar, firewood), as well as thread for making girdles. Sixta is a responsible mother and devoted to her family. Her greatest wish is to be able to provide her youngest son with a quality education and also to improve the quality of life of her special son, so that he continues to feel loved and appreciated by the people that surround him. In the photograph, she is preparing the chicha de jora.

Translated from Spanish by Mark Broscoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of items to make chicha de jora (a drink made from corn)

location.town: Anexo La Piedra - Caserío Punto Cuatro - Mochumí -

loans.name: María Fausta

texts.es:
María es una madre de familia de 38 años de edad que vive junto a su esposo y sus cinco hijos en el sector La Iglesia, perteneciente al distrito de Illimo, ubicado a 45 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Ella divide su tiempo entre el trabajo de casa y el trabajo en el campo, apoya a su esposo en el cuidado de su parcela donde han sembrado frijol y en la crianza de los animales domésticos que utilizan para su alimentación ya que por la zona la carne es escasa y muy cara. Su esposo trabaja como obrero en un molino de arroz de la ciudad de Chiclayo. Con estos ingresos tratan de sacar adelante a su familia.

María se encuentra solicitando por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles con los que quiere terminar de construir su casa, la cual es pequeña y necesita ser reparada urgentemente porque las lluvias que se han presentado durante las temporadas de verano pasadas han debilitado los cimientos de su precaria vivienda.

Ella es una mujer responsable y trabajadora, su más grande anhelo es poder construir su casa de material noble para que puedan vivir tranquilos y seguros durante las temporadas lluviosas del año. En la foto ella nos muestra el material que ha comprado para terminar de construir su casa.
texts.en:
María is a 38 year old housewife who lives with her husband and their five children in the La Iglesia sector of the district of Illimo, located 45 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. She divides her time between housework and working in the field. She supports her husband in taking care of their parcel of land, where they have planted beans, and in the care of the domestic animals they use for food since, in the zone where they live, meat is scarce and very expensive. Her husband works in a rice mill in the city of Chiclayo. With this income they try to move their family ahead.

María is applying with Edpyme Alternativa for the first time for a loan of 1000 new soles with which she wants to complete the construction of her house, which is small and needs urgent repairs because the rains that came during the past spring season have weakened the foundation of her fragile dwelling. She is a responsible and hardworking woman. Her biggest wish is to be able to build her house from strong material so that they can live peacefully and securely during the annual seasonal rains. In the photo she shows us the material she has bought in order to finish constructing her house.

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction material for a house

loans.name: Soraida Azucena

texts.es: La señora Soraida Azucena G. F. vive sola con sus hijos ya que su esposo se fue a las Estados Unidos a trabajar y este le manda dinero para los pagos familiares e imprevistos que sucedan, ella labora para una empresa de promotora desde hace 2 años. Ella esta al cuidado de sus hijos y del hogar; y en estos momentos su hijo se ha enfermado y ella por lo mismo esta tramitando este crédito para la consulta de un medico particular y medicamentos.
texts.en:
Señora Soraida Azucena G. F. lives alone with her children, since her husband went to the United States to work. He sends them money for household and incidental expenses. She has worked for a firm that does sales promotions for 2 years. She takes care of her children and the home; recently her son became sick. For this reason, she is taking out this loan to consult with a doctor and to buy medications.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: expenses of a medical consultation

loans.name: Berbely

texts.es:
La socia BERBERLY, pertenece al banco comunal “PROGRESO DE LOS ANDES”, es natural de la ciudad del Cusco.

La  socia tiene 30 años de edad, es soltera, es docente en educación primaria e inicial,  no tiene hijos y apoya al negocio de su padre. El negocio consiste en vender y comprar madera de la zona de Quillabamba de la provincia de La Convención del departamento del Cusco, hace 15 años que tienen el negocio. Ella y su padre proveen madera a las pequeñas carpinterías de la cuidad del Cusco, la socia necesita el crédito para poder comprar más madera y así pueda aumentar la distribución a más carpinterías e incrementar su comercialización, ella también necesita el crédito para estudiar una Maestría en Docencia Universitaria.   

La socia se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
BERBERLY, 30, is a member of the “PROGRESO DE LOS ANDES" (PROGRESS OF THE ANDES) communal bank. She is from the city of Cusco. She is single and a pre-school and elementary school teacher. She doesn't have any children and helps her father in his business which consists of buying lumber in the Quillabamba zone, which is in the La Convención province in the department of Cusco. They have had this business for the past 15 years. She and her father supply Cusco's small carpentry shops with lumber. She needs this loan to buy more lumber thereby increasing distribution to more carpentry shops which will lead to increased profits. She also needs the loan to study for her Masters Degree in University Teaching. She is grateful for the opportunity this means offers her and pledges to repay her loan in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell lumber.

loans.name: Efrena

texts.en:
Efrena R. is from the village of Poblacion 2, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 47 years old, married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Efrena owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling  different products like coffee,food for snacks,ice candy, soft drinks and other food product in the local community. Efrena has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Efrena joined Kiva partner GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Efrena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. She is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her sixth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About GDMPC
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nila

texts.en:
Nila S. is married to Rodrigo and they have seven children. They live peacefully in the village of Quezon, San Isidro. Hog-raising is the main source of income for Nila. She is thankful for the benefits that she gets from her hog-raising business, and she would like to maintain her business in order to improve her family's standard of living. She is praying that the business would be profitable.

Nila is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP for the maintenance of her business. She will be grateful if her requested loan is granted. This loan will help her to supply her family's needs.

loans.use: As additional capital for the maintenance of her hog-raising business

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
"Perseverance and patience are the weapons needed to attain success in life," says Jocelyn S.. She is 27 years old and still single. Jocelyn has strong determination in life – that’s why she is doing everything to provide for her family. She is an operator of a tricycle in her village.

Jocelyn is asking for financial assistance from Kiva lenders for the maintenance of her tricycle. She is requesting 5,000 Philippine pesos as additional capital to improve her passengered tricycle. Jocelyn is hoping that she can obtain the amount she is requesting for security in case she gets weak. She hopes and prays that she can improve her way of life through the income she can generate with her passengered tricycle.

loans.use: Additional capital for her tricycle maintenance

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes R. operates a business selling goods in a store at the school canteen in her village. She also raises hogs in their backyard. Her husband's source of income is from farming and he also helps Agnes in the hog raising business. At the age of 33, she already has four children. One is in high school and the other three are all in elementary school.

Agnes wants to access a loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos from Kiva lenders to develop and maintain her piggery business. Agnes dreams of developing her business as a source of income to meet the immediate needs of her family. She wants her children to continue their education and finish their studies. Their education is their future – Agnes says that she does not have wealth to give her children other than education.

loans.use: Additional capital to maintain her piggery

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: This is Maria B., 60, from Mulawin, Pasay City - a populous community. She lives with her husband, Jesus, and their six children. Maria has been in business for ten years. She rents out their house’s eight rooms to transients and boarders. She also has a pedicab (rickshaw) and she also sells mineral water and LPG (liquefied petroleum gas). Combined, she earns more than P20,000 a month. She is saving most of her profits in preparation for her husband’s heart surgery. Maria joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2005. She is in need of a new loan of P32,000 for the renovation of her rooms for rent. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To renovate her rooms to rent

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en: Virginia P. is from the village of Banlag, Valencia City. She is 54 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Virginia owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Virginia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
This is Erlinda M., 44, with her five children and her husband Mercelito, an auto mechanic. They live in Malaria, Caloocan City. The couple opened their auto repair shop two years ago along the national highway in Bankers, Tala, Caloocan City. Over time, their shop has gained prominence thanks to their satisfied customers sharing their good experiences with other motorists. They now make at least P12,000.00 net income a month.

Dolores joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative last year to have access to loans to infuse more capital into their business. She recently applied for a P8,000.00 loan to improve their business. The couple dreams of a bigger and more technically advanced auto repair shop someday.

About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Business improvement

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
This is 42-year-old Marivic O. of Tala, Caloocan City, married to Flaviano, a member of a maintenance crew and a part-time painter. They have three children, one in college and another in high school.

Marivic buys old newspapers and magazines from neighbors, then folds and weaves them into fashionable bags and baskets. She does all of this in the comfort of her home. She learned about this industry 16 years ago through the initiative of the local government which trained women, including her, in the basics of the trade. In addition, Marivic buys and sells religious scapulars, earning P6,000.00 a month from her activities.

Marivic joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative just last year but is already impressed at how the cooperative takes care of its members. She has just finished repaying her third loan with CCT and has applied for a P10,000.00 loan to infuse more capital into her business.

About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Khurshid

texts.en:
Khurshid, the son of M. Wail, lives in shewa of Nangrahar province. He works hard in agriculture because he feels a lot of responsibility toward his family members as the eldest son in the family. He lives in a family of 10 members including his father and mother. 

Khurshid wants to apply for an individual loan of 50000 Afghani for the purpose of purchasing more seeds and materials for his farm. 
He hopes to expand and bring new changes in his business. He is confident that he can repay his loan on time and plans to join the second cycle loan after the full repayment of the first cycle loan. He would like to extend his gratitude to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and farming stocks

loans.name: Farhad

texts.en:
This is a picture of Farhad, son of Zemarai, who lives in Jalalabad city. He is the oldest son in his family and holds many responsibilities for his family members. He lives in a family of eight, including his father and mother.

Farhad has a general store where he sells a wide range of items. He is asking for an individual loan of 50000 Afghani for the purpose of purchasing more good quality food items and materials for his shop. He wants to attract more clients by purchasing high demand items for his market. He hopes to improve his business by bringing new changes to it. He is confident that he can repay his loan on time and plans to join the second cycle loan after the full repayment of the first cycle loan. He would like to extend his gratitude to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more food items for store

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
This is Dolores S., 43 years old, with her husband Amancio, a shoe repairman. They live in Camarin, Caloocan City. Their eldest child is now in college and the youngest is in high school. Dolores owns a small general store where she sells, among other things, second-hand shoes which her husband salvages and repairs. They’ve been doing this for the last ten years, earning about P12,000.00 a month. The children’s education is their top priority, so Dolores budgets a substantial portion of her profits for their education. She is now on her 3rd loan cycle with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative and is requesting a loan of P8,000.00 to improve her business.

About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: He wants to complete his stocks.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
This is Rose A., 38 years old, a walking manicurist who lives in Tala, Caloocan City. Her husband Romeo, 34, is a construction foreman. They have four children. Rose provides home service manicures and pedicures to her customers. She learned and started to put into practice this money-making venture three years ago, earning more than P600.00 per day.

Rose became a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative last year. She is now on her eighth loan cycle and has just recently applied for a loan in the amount of P12,000.00. to buy a new manicure set, nail colors (polish), and other supplies for her business.

She is working hard to finance her children’s education and also wants to have her own parlor/salon.

About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Said Pacha

texts.en:
Said Pacha is an old man. He is an uneducated man, but he has lots of experience. He has a retail shop in Jalalabad that he has been involved in for more than 10 years. Before this loan, he worked in agriculture in his own town. He now has the responsibility of his family. During the last 10 years he tried many times to enlarge his shop but he was unable. When he found AFS (Ariana Financial Services Joint stock Company) in Jalalabad he was very happy and decided to apply for a loan.

Now he is requesting an individual loan of 50000 Afghanis to enlarge his shop and to further his business. With more success and strength in his business, he will make a good monthly income for his family.

Sayed Pacha wants to thank lenders around the world and to thank Kiva and AFS. He would like to say thanks from all who support him with this fantastic loan process. 
He says that people in Jalalabad, Afghanistan have been faced with lots of difficulties and he would love to see more success with this program in the future.

loans.use: He wants to comlete his stocks.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet P., 26 years old and the married mother of three school-aged children, is from the village of Sinayawan, Valencia City. To make a living, Janet owns and operates a specialized retail store whose main income comes from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Janet has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Janet joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to to purchase additional products to sell, Janet is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP for the same purpose.This will be her second loan from HSPFI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mohammad Hamed

texts.en:
The man pictured is Mohammad Hamed, the son of A. A.. He is 40, married , and has 5 children. He lives with his wife and five children in Bagrami Kabul Afghanistan Kamare Damana village. 

In the mentioned city, Mohammad Hamed has owned a small piece of land where he works hard to complete the requirements of his land and he buys seeds to cultivate his land. He is the only person in the family who has all the responsibilities for his family members.

He has requested an individual loan of 50000 and his only purpose is to expand his business. He would like to say that Kiva is an effective process that can support all the entrepreneurs to start a business and to sustain it as well.

loans.use: buying seeds and essential things

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji S. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste, tomatoes, etc. and is requesting a loan to purchase onions and cooking oil to sell. Keji is 35 years old and married to a nurse. They have six children, all attending school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase onions and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Oscar

texts.en:
“If you are industrious, you will have plenty of food,” says Oscar P. Sr., the industrious husband of Telma P.. They live in a village located at Brgy. Lactawan, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya and are blessed with five children, four boys and one girl, all of whom have finished their studies in college. Three of them are presently working abroad, while the others are managing a business.

The common source of their living is through cultivation of their farmland by planting rice and some vegetables. During harvest season, they can earn a net income of P 35,000.00 which they use to both sustain their daily basic needs and save for their future. At present, Oscar is requesting an amount of P 30,000.00 to acquire needed agricultural supplies including fertilizers and pesticides for the maintenance of their crop production. He believes that he can increase his harvest and income with the help of the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy farming inputs

loans.name: Oscar

texts.en:
Oscar P. Jr. is now 29 years old, after his college education. He is married to Jemarie P., and they are gifted with a child named Jem Anne Nychole, who is 5 years old. They want her to become successful in the future so that she can take care of them when they get old. They help each other to earn an income to satisfy their basic needs and save for the future of their daughter.

Oscar Jr. is engaged in hog raising, and he also cultivates rice and some vegetables, while his wife is engaged in selling snacks and vegetables in their village, located at Brgy. Lactawan, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. The fruit of his patience and sacrifices, he earns an income of not less than 30,000 PHP per harvest, which they utilize to acquire their daily needs while saving some for the future of their children. Because of their interest in improving their standard of living, Oscar applied for a loan amounting to 20,000 PHP to be used in purchasing seeds, fertilizers, and pesticides for the maintenance of their crop production. He wishes that his loan will be approved, to be able to have a good harvest.

loans.use: Additional capital for the maintenance of his crop production

loans.name: Florencio

texts.en:
Florencio H., 53 years old, is married to Lolita, who is a market vendor in their town. The couple is blessed with four loving children: Marites, 28, who works in a tutorial center; Richard, 26, who is a tricycle driver; Marilyn, 17, who is a first-year college student; and the youngest, Donabel, 10, who is currently enrolled in elementary-level education.

The family resides in Sta. Maria, a small village of Alicia, Isabela. Florencio's main source of income is through motorcycle transport, where he earns a daily net income of 500 PHP. Aside from that, he also cultivates the small farm at the back of their house to have additional income. His desire to acquire more income motivated him to borrow a loan in the amount of 6,000 PHP from some lenders for additional working capital in his business. According to him, patience and diligence are the best characteristics for a productive life.

loans.use: The maintenance and repair of his motorcycle

loans.name: Esmeralda

texts.en:
Esmeralda C., 59 years old, and her husband Nolasco, also 59, have been farming for forty years now. Nolasco also drives for a living. They have six children. They live together in the breezy town of Silang, Cavite.

When they are in season, Esmeralda trades bananas, pineapples, and other crops from their farm in the nearby market. But while waiting for the harvest to come in, she gets to attend to her general store (as shown in the picture). She is earning close to 26,000 PHP a month. She uses her profits and other savings to send her children to school; they still have two college students. Esmeralda is proud enough to declare that four of their six children finished college out of their earnings. She was also able to purchase a jeepney, which they are now using to deliver fruits and other crops to the market.

Esmeralda joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2005. She loves the camaraderie of the women entrepreneurs. She is applying for a new loan in the amount of 24,000 PHP, which she will use to fund the next pineapple crop. She will purchase fertilizers, pesticides, and other farm tools. Some of the funds will be used to purchase grocery items to sell at her store.

Esmeralda wishes to get rich so she can help her poor neighbors and relatives. Her usual prayers include good health and harmonious relationships amongst her children.

About CCT: The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical missions in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, pesticides, and additional grocery items

loans.name: Estelita

texts.en: Estelita is 46 years old and already married. She is managing a store in the village of Gud, San Isidro. She is thankful because her store is improving, but still she would like to maintain this kind of business. Estelita would like to buy additional merchandise, but her capital is not enough. So far, she is requesting a loan amounting to 5,000 PHP that she will be using to purchase additional merchandise. This amount that she is requesting will be a big help in her business improvement, so she is praying that this amount will be granted.

loans.use: Additional capital to purchase more merchandise for her store

loans.name: Nadera Group

texts.en:
This is the Nadera group. This group is made up of three female members. Nadera is the group leader. She is about 50 years old, married and has 6 children. She has got a shared business with her husband. Her husband has a fruit selling shop. Nadera cleans and packages the fresh fruits and then her husband sells the fruit at a good price in his shop.

The second member is Fozia. She wants to receive a loan for her brother’s cassette selling shop. With the loan he would like to purchase more cassettes and will make his shop larger.
And the last member of the group is Noorbebe. He wants to take a loan for his son’s fuel selling shop. With the loan his son wants to expand his business and to buy the required materials for his shop. 
Together, they have requested a group loan of 42,000 Afghani to change the status of their businesses and their life.
They would like to commend this effective process.

loans.use: Towards expanding their businesses.

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora P. is currently in the business of selling various items in a retail shop, like coffee, beans, soap, etc., and is requesting a loan to stock more goods in her shop to sell. Flora is 35 years old and is married, with a husband that is a policeman. She has 4 children, and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs, as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more goods in her shop to sell

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn B. has been managing a village store for almost a year now. She buys her goods from Cauayan City once a week, to lessen the transportation expenses. Her business is a good source of income for her family as it is where they get their daily allowances. She hopes that her business will become more competent with the help of the loan she is requesting. She hopes that KIVA lenders will grant her PHP 5,000 to use as additional revolving capital for her business. She plans to buy additional commodities such as biscuits, canned goods and other products that her customers may need. 

Evelyn is the kind of a businesswoman who is very optimistic. She always takes everything positively, especially when it comes to her store. She anticipates that her retail store will expand with the help of KIVA lenders, that’s why she really prays that her loan request will be granted. Evelyn is already married. She and her husband have already been blessed with a child who is presently studying. She wishes to give her child everything that she needs, thus she works diligently on developing her business.

loans.use: additional revolving capital for her general store.

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en: Milagros is engaged in a hog-raising business. She is 57 years of age and single. She has been blessed with one child. Maria Eleonor, 16 years old, is now a high school graduate. As father and mother to her only child, Milagros is doing everything she can to sustain her needs. Milagros is praying and hoping that she can provide for all their needs through the income that she generates from her hog-raising business. Milagros would like to ask for additional capital from the KIVA lenders for the maintenance of her pigs. In this regard, she is requesting a loan in the amount of PHP 5,000. This loan amount will be utilized to buy feed for the pigs. She hopes that her loan request will be granted.

loans.use: additional capital to buy feed for pigs.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is engaged in a retailing business in her village. She plants different vegetables in her backyard for additional vegetables to sell. When she has no produce yet, she buys vegetables at the market of Cauayan City and retails them in her village. She hopes to have additional funds to buy fertilizers for her vegetable garden and additional capital to buy fresh vegetables from the market. She is requesting a loan amount of PHP 4,000 and she hopes that it will be granted.

Jocelyn is a patient businesswoman who never loses hope, no matter how hard life is. She is always ready to work for the welfare of her children, who are still studying. She is thankful to her husband because he plows and cultivates their vegetable garden with her on their farm. Their family is happily residing in the village of Cabaruan, Naguilian, Isabela.

loans.use: to buy more fresh vegetables and fertilizer.

loans.name: Hameda Group

texts.en:
This is Hameda group. There are four female members in this group. These women would like to progress and develop their businesses. 
Hameda is the group leader. She wants to take a loan for her husband who has car parts shop. Hameda’s husband needs to cover all the necessities for his family and pay for all the expenses. He wants to buy some tools with the Kiva loan. He is confident that, after the loan, he can increase his business. 

Shakiba wants to receive a loan for her husband, who has fuel-selling shop. Shakiba’s husband wants to buy more fuel for his business. 

Khmela wants to take a loan for her husband who has oil-selling shop. Khmela’s husband wants to buy all the materials he needs for his business. 

Amina wants to take a loan for her husband who has general store. Amina’s husband wants to expand his business and to buy some more materials for his shop to attract more clients. He wants to buy all the required materials to have a well-organized shop. They are requesting a group loan of 40,000 Afghani. They admire this effective process.

loans.use: For business progress.

loans.name: Ayuru

texts.en:
Ayuru A. is currently in the business of selling charcoal.  She is requesting a loan to purchase cooking oil and onions to sell. Ayuru is 35 years old. She is widowed.   She has 6 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase cooking oil and onions to sell.

loans.name: Melanda

texts.en:
“Achieving success in life is not that easy, due to many struggles that you will undergo,” says Melanda B.. She is married to Antonio who manages their rice farming and, at the same time, he is a carpenter within their village. The couple would like to have a better standard of living. This is why they are striving hard to provide for the needs of their family. 

Through her business she is able to provide for their daily needs. According to Melanda, she wants to buy additional merchandise for her store so that she can also generate a bigger income. But, due to insufficient capital, she would like to ask for additional capital from the KIVA lenders in the amount of PHP 5,000. She is hoping and praying that this loan amount she is requesting will be granted for her business expansion and improvement.

loans.use: For additional capital to buy more merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Shogofa Halema Group

texts.en:
This pictured group is made up of three members and is named the Shogofa Halema group. They would like to receive a group loan of 30000 Afghani. Halema, who is 55, is the group leader. She is married with 7 children and is a widow. She lost her husband during the war in Kabul, Afghanistan, so after her husband she was the only one who was able to manage the house and the expenses because her children were small. She is in the business of quilt sewing from her house, and she is quite popular with her work because she has almost 35 years of experience. She has received one loan to buy good quality materials.

The second member, Mahboba, wants to use her loan to purchase a new sewing machine for her tailoring business, and Habibullah wants to expand his business of selling cigarettes. Currently he has a cart, but with the loan he wants to have a small shop.

They are all happy that they will be able to progress through the Kiva loan process.

loans.use: To purchase their needed materials

loans.name: Maria Liza

texts.en:
Maria Liza is married to Henry R. and they have three children: Mark Joseph, 21, college graduate; Mary Joy, 19, college student; Henry, Jr., nine years old, elementary student. 

Maria Liza’s family has cooperation with each other. She is now focusing on her general store business and, at the same time, she is vending meats to the local villagers.  Mari Liza would like to improve their way of living through her business. She would like to help her husband to earn an income but her capital is not enough. This is why she has decided to request a loan of PHP 5,000 from KIVA lenders for business improvement and expansion. She is hoping that she can receive this amount of loan for the improvement of their living conditions.

loans.use: For additional capital for business improvement.

loans.name: Maruim

texts.en: This is Maruim, daughter of Z.. She lives in district 2nd of Kabul Afghanistan. She is a young girl of 25 years. Even though she is so young, she still feels lots of responsibilities towards her family members. She lives in a family of 7, including her father and mother. She is the oldest daughter in her family and Maruim wants to take a loan for the business of tailoring. Since the Taliban regime she has sewn clothes. At that time they had lots of economic problems. Now, with the Kiva loan she wants to support her family members. She has requested a group loan of 14000 Afghani ($300US). She would like to mention the effectiveness of the Kiva loan process and its effect on their business progress.

loans.use: For expanding business.

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda is a forty-one year old businesswoman. She resides, together with her family, in the village of Cabaruan, Naguilian, Isabela. She is married and has three children who are all studying. Imelda dreams to succeed in her business. She says that no matter how big the trials she is facing, she is always optimistic to help her husband provide for their daily needs especially towards the education of their children. She hopes to uplift her family’s general living conditions. With the help of her husband and generous people around, she believes that someday she will become successful.

Imelda is engaged in hog-raising. She wishes to increase the number of pigs to be raised for her to acquire more income. She is requesting a loan amounting to PHP 4,000 to purchase feed to sustain the healthy growth of her hogs. Imelda shared that, with her perseverance, she can somehow purchase another pig to raise.

loans.use: to purchase feeds for her hog

loans.name: Ireda Agali 1 Judith Ocen Group

texts.en: Judith O. is a business lady of twenty-five years of age. She is married with two children in schooling and she takes care of three additional dependents who are in schooling as well. She is dealing with a tailoring business, which she has been doing for four years so far. She is using the loan to purchase fabric for making clothes in different designs. She is requesting the loan to purchase clothing material especially for the Christmas season. She wants to improve upon her business so that she will experience some change. She is active and hardworking. Her dream is to raise her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase clothing material, especially for Christmas season.

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella is a businesswoman who is now fifty years old. She is married and has three young children. Their family lives in the village of Cabaruan, Naguilian, Isabela.  As a mother, she dreams to give her children the education they deserve. For this reason, she is doing her part to provide for the needs of her children and to help them reach their dreams.

Estrella plants some vegetables in their backyard, which gives her a little source of income. She sells them in their village. Aside from that her family’s daily consumption of vegetables comes from her vegetable garden. In addition, she also manages a livestock business. Estrella is asking to borrow a loan of PHP 4,000 to buy fertilizers for her vegetables and feed for her hogs. She hopes that this loan will be granted because it will be of big help towards the maintenance of her businesses.

loans.use: For additional capital to buy fertilizers and feed for her hogs.

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy is 30 years old, an ordinary villager of Barangay Caritan, Tuguegarao City. She is married to Jhun G., 34, a local tricycle driver. They are blessed with two gifted children: the elder is Jhon Llyod, 11 years old, a grade V pupil. The younger is Jersey Joy, 10 years old, a grade IV pupil. Both of Joy's children are enrolled in a public school in their community. The couple hopes that their children will also finish their college degree.

Motorcycle transport is the primary source of income for Joy and her husband Jhun. Aside from the transport business, Joy is also engaged in raising native chickens to earn extra income.

For the continuous development of their motorcycle transport business and her poultry business. Joy is requesting a loan amounting to PHP 6,000 from KIVA lenders. She hopes that her loan will be approved so as to enable her business to grow and earn more profit.

loans.use: additional capital for business development

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn is busy running her hog-raising business. She is married to Andres who works as a farmer in their village. They have been blessed with one child, Aiverson, seven years old, who is a grade II pupil. Analyn and her husband help one another to further improve their way of living. Her husband is busy cultivating their rice fields in order for them to have a high yield.

Through the sacrifices and patience of Analyn, she is able to provide the needs of her family with the help of her loving and responsible husband. She would like to buy feed for her pigs to further minimize her expenses going to and from the market. In this regard, she is requesting a loan amounting to PHP 5,000 for the feed for her hog-raising business.

loans.use: additional capital to buy feed for her hogs

loans.name: Ireda Agali 2 Santa Ogwal Group

texts.en: Santa O. is twenty-three years old and married with three children, of whom two are schooling. She is dealing with produce such as beans, maize, rice, etc. She hopes to change the business to the next level and more, since she really wants to change her standard of living. She is requesting the loan to purchase produce such as beans, maize, rice, etc. for sale. She is a hard-working business lady whose dream is to construct a house.

loans.use: To purchase produce such as beans, maize, rice, etc. for sale.

loans.name: Eldaniz

texts.en:
Eldaniz is applying to Kiva for a second loan. He sells clothes. Eldaniz needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy clothes to expand his clothing sales business. At this moment he sells children's clothing. Now he plans to sell clothes for adults also. The weather is becoming cold and he would like to buy the warm clothes for sale.

"I am very thankful to Kiva lenders for the loan. With your help I improved my business and I cannot ever forget that," Eldaniz says.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Nena

texts.en:
Nena is engaged to Alexander M.. This couple are blessed with three children: Melanie-28 years old, a college graduate; Mylene-25 years old, college level; and Michelle-23 years old who is an undergraduate in college.

Nena is a chicken raiser in the village of Quezon, San Isidro. She would like to buy additional chicks to raise to make more income and to improve their way of living. In this regard, she would like to take out a loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP 5,000. This amount would be a big help in achieving her goals in life, so she is hoping that this loan amount will be approved.

loans.use: additional capital to buy more chicks to raise

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios P. is from the village of Palacapao, Quezon Bukidnon. She is 64 years old. Remedios is married and has 2 children. To make a living, Remedios owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Remedios has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Remedios joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Remedios is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Remedios from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma, 58 years old, is running a hog raising business. Her business is located in the village of Quezon, San Isidro. She is married to Leonardo who works as a farmer. Whenever Leonardo is not busy in their farm, he sometimes works as a carpenter in their village.

Wanting to purchase sacks of feed for her hogs, Wilma decided to request a loan from KIVA lenders amounting to Php5,000. She said that she will be very thankful if the loan is granted. She hopes that through the loan and with her patience and hard work, she will succeed in her journey because she really dreams of a better future for her seven children.

loans.use: additional capital for buying feed for her hogs

loans.name: Ireda Agali 2 Okello Lucy Group

texts.en: O. Lucy is forty-two years old, widowed and blessed with six children of whom, five are schooling. She operates a local brewing business which she has been running for  ten years so far. She is requesting this loan to purchase local brewing ingredients such as maize flour, yeast, etc.. She is trying to improve her business to make more profit so that she will be able to pay school fees for her children. She is not worrying because there is some thing to eat. She is active and her dream is to build a house for her children.

loans.use: to purchase local brewing ingredients such as maize flour, yeast, etc.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena P. is from the village of Valencia City. She is 55 years old. Elena is married and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Elena owns and operates a business venture in the food sector, making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Elena has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Elena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.
