Elena is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Elena from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji L. is currently in the business of selling beer at a bar and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell. Keji is 35 years old and is married to a husband who is a soldier. She has 2 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy more fridges and extend the floor of her bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stocking more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice N. is 36 years old without children and lives alone. Her home is in Burera district, the Northern Province of Rwanda, approximately three hours from Kigali, the capital city.

Recognizing the need to make a living for herself, Beatrice started a business buying and selling potatoes three year ago and has been successful, despite not having any previous experience. Her business is such that it requires her to work from 7 a.m. to 4 p.m. every day.

Beatrice is requesting her second loan from Vision Finance Company - it is worth noting that her first loan was paid back on time and in full. This second loan will add to her working capital and and allow her to purchase more and better quality potatoes at better prices in order to attract new customers.

Through accessing this loan, if her expansion plans are successful, Beatrice will able to continue her life as a self-employed woman with a successful enterprise and build a stronger business and a more secure future for herself.

loans.use: To purchase more potatoes and supplies

loans.name: Ireda Agali 2 Okello Lilly Group

texts.en: O. Lilly is forty-seven years old. She is widowed and blessed with eight children. She is dealing in the charcoal business. She has been selling charcoal for over three years. She was managing to purchase at least three to four bags of charcoal. She is requesting for a loan to purchase at least ten to fifteen bags of charcoal to get better profits for her business. She is very hard-working and her dream is to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase at least ten to fifteen bags of charcoal to get better profits for her business.

loans.name: John

texts.en: John G., 31 years old, has two primary businesses: a cell phone kiosk and transportation for hire with his pick-up truck. He operates out of a market setting in Kangemi town, and his kiosk offers "top-off' cards for cell phones, M-Pesa payment capabilities as well as other cell phone accessories. In addition to his two businesses, John has a garden where he grows cash crops of maize, beans and potatoes. His business challenges are security for the kiosk and a lack of funds for expansion.  John is using his loan of KES 20,000 to increase his working capital. His business goals are to concentrate on M-Pesa and to purchase more vehicles for tranportation.  John has a wife, who works with him at the kiosk, and one child.  He describes himself as hardworking and he serves as the treasurer of his borrowing group, Carnivore 2009.

loans.use: Increase working capital.

loans.name: Moise

texts.en:
Moise N. is 25 years old, single, and lives in the Northern Province of Rwanda, approximately three hours drive from the capital city of Kigali. His village, called Rwambogo, is where he has his transport business and he will continue to operate there.

Issa is requesting his first loan in order to buy a new motorbike to replace his old bike which needs replacing very much. This motorcycle allows him to earn a living as a moto-taxi driver with a monthly income of nearly 100,000 RWF (approximately US$180). His moto-taxi transport business has been open every day from 6 in the morning to 8 in the evening since 2006 as long as there are customers to drive.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Alejandra

texts.en: Alejandra B. is from the village of Alegria. She is 58 years old, is married, and has one adult child. Alejandra owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2006, Alejandra joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase piglets to raise and sell. Alejandra is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. This loan will be her 3rd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies

loans.name: Cherry

texts.en:
Cherry yields patience and diligence for the success of her business. She has managed a retail store in their village for almost five years, where she sometimes sells vegetables. Her weekly net income in her store is PHP300. They have also a half-hectare of rice farm, which is being manage by her husband. She is requesting a loan amounting to PHP 7,000 from KIVA lenders for additional capital in her business. She will use the funds mainly for buying stocks of commodities such as detergent soap, biscuits, canned goods, soft drinks and many other products. 

She is married to Aurelio Q., who works as a farmer and a tricycle driver. They have been blessed with a son, named Niloor Bonnil, who is only 4 years of age. They are harmoniously residing at the rural area of Sta. Maria, Alicia, Isabela. She hopes that KIVA lenders will grant her request of a loan to help her husband in earning money to support their daily needs.

loans.use: Additional capital for buying more commodities for her retail store.

loans.name: Uwe

texts.en:
Uwe G. is currently in the business of selling rice and beans and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of rice and beans to sell.  Uwe is 30 years old and is married to a husband that is a peasant. She has 6 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of rice to sell.

loans.name: Issa

texts.en:
Issa K. is 41 years old and is married with four children aged 3 through 14. He and his family live in the Musanze district in the Northern Province of Rwanda.

Issa has been an entrepreneur for five years in selling beans,rice,maize,sorghum in his local community. He employs 3 people in his business and his shop is open early every day, starting from 5 in the morning to 6 in the evening.

Issa is requesting his first loan from Vision Finance Company in order to have sufficient capital to purchase more foodstuff for his shop which he thinks will attract more customers. With this loan he hopes to increase his business and build a more secure future for himself and his young family.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuff

loans.name: Zacharia

texts.en: Zacharia K. owns the Zach Chemist kiosk where he sells cosmetics, drug store items and photocopying services. He also has a barber-shop. Competition in both his businesses is strong. Zacharia is using his loan of KES 20,000 to increase stock of drug store products and over-the-counter medicines. In the future, he wants to be a wholesaler and to stabilize in his business. Zacharia has a wife who works as a teacher and they have a nine-month-old daughter. He describes himself as social, friendly and he serves as the secretary of his borrowing group, Carnivore 2009.

loans.use: To increase stock of drug store products.

loans.name: Ireda Agali 2 Among Jenate Group

texts.en: A. Jenate is twenty-four years old. She is married with three children, of which, two children are going to school. She is dealing with produce and it is, so far, three years that she has had her business. She is using the loan to purchase produce such as beans, maize, etc. to add stock to her business. She is interesting and active and her dream is to construct a new house.

loans.use: To purchase produce such as beans, maize, etc to add stock to her business.

loans.name: Jaqueline

texts.en:
Jaqueline M. is 31 years old and is married with three children aged 1, 4 and 7. Jaqueline and her family live in Rwaza district in the Northern Province of Rwanda.

Jaqueline has a small shop selling a wide variety of products, such as: rice, sugar, biscuits, water, cooking oil, juice, cosmetics products, candy and bread, to name a few. Since she has been in business since 2006, this is her third year of successful operation. The hours of her shop are from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. every day.

Jaqueline is requesting her fourth loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders in order to expand her business through purchasing some other attractive products. This will help her to serve more customers and, hopefully, earn more profit in the process. Also, the shop inventory purchasing requires credit and capital which these loans have provided her.

It is worth noting that Jaqueline has paid back all previous loans on time and in full. The loans are allowing her to grow her business slowly and put aside money so that she will be able to pay school fees for her children as they grow older.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Mary Rose

texts.en: Mary Rose is 40 years old and is married to Jessie. The couple is blessed with two children: Aljay, 15 years old, in high school and Mart Andrew, 10 years old, elementary student. Mary Rose would like to improve their way of living through asking for additional capital from the KIVA lenders in the amount of PHP 5,000. Mary Rose is a tricycle operator within their village. Her husband is the one who manages their passengered tricycle. Mary Rose would like to earn a bigger income for their children needs. That’s why she and her husband are striving to work hard for the future welfare of their children. She will be glad if her requested loan will be granted.

loans.use: For additional capital for the maintenance of her tricycle business.

loans.name: Marceline

texts.en:
Marceline M. is 33 years old and is married with four children aged 4 through 11. She and her family live in the Nyamagabe district of the Gikongoro province of Rwanda where her business of selling general vegetables and fruits is located.

Marceline has been a successful businesswoman for the past eight years and her shop is well regarded by the locals. Her shop is open from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Marceline is requesting her second loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders in order to expand her business. She plans to purchase greater quantities and varieties of foods for sale which she believes her customers will want to buy. Through accessing this loan, she plans to increase her monthly profits, which will help her to pay school fees for her four young children.

loans.use: To buy more fruit, produce and general foods to sell

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna P. is from the village of Colonia, Valencia City. She is 45 years old. Myrna is married and has school-aged children. To make a living, Myrna owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Myrna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Myrna is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Myrna from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Domitila

texts.en:
Domitila N. is 36 years old and is married without children. She lives with her parents in Burera district, in the Northern Province of Rwanda where she recently opened a foodstuffs shop.

Domitila has an experience of three years in this career of selling potatoes. Her small shop is open every day from 7 a.m. to 4 p.m. .

Domitila is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders in order to purchase more potatoes that will help her to serve more customers. Through this service, she hopes to earn more profit than previously.

loans.use: To purchase more potatoes

loans.name: Atoniata

texts.en:
Atoniata L. is currently in the business of selling beer in a bar and is requesting a loan to buy more crates of beer to sell in her bar. Atoniata is 28 years old and is widowed.  She has one child and her child does not go to school yet. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: buy more crates of beer to sell.

loans.name: Glen

texts.en: Glen B. is from the village of Highway Lawis. She is 24 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Glen owns and operates a furniture making business, making and selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2003, Glen joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. Glen is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 11th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: El

texts.en: El A. is 29 years old and has been selling fresh fish in the local busy market for more than three years. She sells fish that she buys from her wholesale supplier or from the river, where there are many fishermen. She is married with a school-aged child. Her husband is a used-clothes trader (he appears in the picture). El A. is taking out her loan to buy a motorcycle, which she will use for transporting the fish to sell at the market.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle which she will use for transporting fish to sell at the market.

loans.name: Eliud

texts.en:
Eliud O. owns the Purple Hut salon located on a retail street in the town of Kangemi.  His clients are primarily middle-class women. He offers plaiting, haircuts and sets, manicures and pedicures. His business challenges are lack of capital and strong competition in the area. 

He is using the proceeds of 20,000 Kenyan shilling loan to increase his stock of beauty products. His business goals are to have a larger salon in Kangemi and to establish some satellite branches. Eliud has a wife and a 3-year-old son. He describes himself as smart, hardworking and successful. He serves as the chairman of the Carnivore 2009 borrowing group.

loans.use: To buy more beauty products

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline P. is from the village of Panadtalan, Valencia Bukidnon. She is 29 years old. Evangeline is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Evangeline operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling flavored ice drops in the local community. Evangeline has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2009, Evangeline joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evangeline is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Evangeline from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ireda Agali 3 Akao Agnes Group

texts.en:
Agnes A. is 35 years old. She is married and the mother of six children who are in school. She is also looking after her father in her home. She has been in the bakery business for over nine years. 

She is requesting the loan in order to improve upon her business by adding capital, getting an alarm for proper timing and adding more manpower for more profits. She is a courageous and hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to purchase a motorcycle for transporting her goods to shops, supermarkets and other marketplaces.

loans.use: To add capital, get an alarm for proper timing and add manpower for more profits

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is already 39 years old and is married to Graciano N.. They live peacefully in the village of Nagassican, Santiago City, together with their child, Reymond, who is already 11 years old.

Evelyn manages a home-based store and at the same time she is vending viands (tasty dishes) in order to have another source of income. She is thankful because her business is improving, but she still needs to continue improving it so that she can sustain the financial needs of her family.

Evelyn would like to obtain a loan of Php 5,000 as additional capital for purchasing her merchandise and for the improvement of her viands-vending business. She is hoping that her loan request will be granted for the welfare of her child.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her store and her vending business

loans.name: Tereza

texts.en: Tereza S. is currently in the business of operating a retail shop and is requesting a loan to buy more goods like Blue Band (brand name foods), sugar, soap, etc., to sell in her shop. Tereza is 27 years old and is married to a businessman. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, Tereza hopes to be able to build a bigger shop. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her store

loans.name: Alihuseyn

texts.en: Alihuseyn lives in Baku city. He was born in 1987 and is single. Alihuseyn not only has a business selling computers, but he also repairs them. He has been in this business for two years. Now he is requesting a loan of 2000 AZN to improve his business.

loans.use: To improve his business.

loans.name: Merly

texts.en: Merly M. is from the village of Unidos. She is 38 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Merly owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month. In 2009, Merly joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Merly is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 2nd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en: Nelson B. is 51 years old. He has been engaged in mushroom production for almost three weeks now and he also has a vegetable plantation. He has been selling fruits and vegetables for three years in the public market and earns a net income of PHP 400.00 per week. He would like to request a loan from KIVA lenders in the amount of PHP 5,000.00 to buy more goods to sell. He would like to earn enough money to pay for the schooling of his three children. Nelson is married to Emilyn B., who works as a midwife in their town. They have blessed with loving children. The eldest, named Scarlet, is 28 and a third year college student. She is followed by Kelvin, who is 19 and also a third year college student. Their youngest, Kimberly, is 12 and a second year high school student. Their family is happily residing in the rural village of Sta. Maria. Their house is near the rice fields. Nelson hopes that KIVA lenders will grant him this loan.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Ireda Agali 3 Alumu Evelyn Group

texts.en: Evelyn A. is a 26 year old business lady. She is married and the mother of four children, three of whom go to school. She has been in the charcoal business since 2008. Although the taxes are high, she doesn’t give up. Evelyn is requesting this loan to purchase 15 or more bags of charcoal. As well, she would like to expand her grocery business by acquiring produce such as beans, maize, rice, etc to sell. She is an organized, hardworking business lady whose future hope is to educate her children and obtain a somewhat easier lifestyle.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal and produce

loans.name: Gaudencia

texts.en:
Gaudencia is a very religious person who always puts God first in whatever she does. She is 26 years old and resides in the village of Caritan, Tuguegarao City, together with her husband and four children: Novie, 27; Noel, 25; Nardo, 23; and Norma, 21.

As a mother, Gaudencia is hoping to provide the best future for her children. For that reason, she is striving hard to maintain her business and hopes that someday she will be able to extend it to become a more stable business.

Gaudencia has been engaged in a chicken-raising business behind their backyard for two years now. She needs additional capital to purchase more native chickens to raise, and for their supply of feeds and medicines.

For her second loan, she is requesting PHP 5,000 for the maintenance and growth of her poultry raising business. She is hoping that her loan will be approved because it will contribute a lot to the progress of her business as well as to their living conditions.

loans.use: To buy more chickens to raise, plus feeds and medicines for her poultry

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en: Hellen M. is currently in the business of retailing in her shop by selling beans, rice, sugar, etc., and is requesting a loan to buy more goods such as: cups, plates, jerrycans, etc. Hellen is 25 years old and is married to a soldier. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a new shop. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her store

loans.name: Everlina

texts.en:
The buying and selling of vegetables is the main source of income of Everlina P.. She and her husband are working hand in hand in preparing their small parcel of land. Though preparing the land and planting is difficult, they still don't mind at all because they really desire a productive life for their children.

Everlina is married to Richard who, according to her, is very supportive and loving. The couple is blessed with two children, namely: Rhea, 13 years old, a first year high school student; and Mary Grace, 7, a grade II pupil.

Desiring to make her business more productive, Everlina decided to borrow Php 5,000 from Kiva lenders to buy fertilizer for their vegetables and to buy other fresh vegetables in their market.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and more fresh vegetables to sell

loans.name: Ireda Agali 3 Atimango Lucy Group

texts.en:
A. Lucy is representing her group. She is a businesswoman, thirty-eight years old, and married with five children, all schooling. More so, she is taking care of two dependents.

Lucy deals in produce and charcoal. She takes produce such as beans, cabbages, rice, maize, etc., to Abim district, Karamoja, and purchases charcoal from deep villages in Abim to market in Lira district. She has stayed in this business for over six years.

Because of the war impact in Abim district, there is no food and that is why Lucy targeted supplying or marketing her produce in Abim.

Lucy is requesting the loan to purchase more stock so that she can add capital into her business. She is a very hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to give her children a bright future: that is, by educating them.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her business

loans.name: Rozia Group

texts.en:
This is Rozia group. It has four female members. These women would like to progress and develop their businesses.
Rozia is the group leader. She has a beauty salon and is busy working there in order to support her husband and five of her children who are students. Using the loan she plans to purchase more new design cosmetics for her beauty salon to expand it and attract more clients.
Maleha wants to use her loan to buy the materials for carpet weaving so she can have more good quality ones. She buys one kilo of her materials for 1500 Afghani.
Sohila tailors in her house. She has arranged a small room where she sews different kinds of clothes and has a good number of clients. Using the loan she wants to buy an electric sewing machine because she has lots of problems using her old one.
The last member, Latifa, wants a loan for her husband’s general store because he needs to buy the things which are not available in his shop.
They all have requested a group loan of 56000 Afghani.
They would like to mention the effectiveness of the Kiva process and its positive effect on their business progress.

loans.use: Expanding their businesses

loans.name: Norma

texts.en: Norma E. is from the village of Calacaan. She is 48 years old, is married, and has three adult children. Norma owns and operates a manufacturing business, manufacturing and selling products to local businesses and community members. Norma has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month. In 2004, Norma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding her business. Norma is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional raw materials to expand her product offerings. This loan will be her 9th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional raw materials to expand her product offerings

loans.name: Vet

texts.en: Fish is the main source of food for a great majority of Cambodians and many Cambodian people depend on catching fish to earn a living. One of these people is 35 year old Vet D.. Him and his wife wake up when the sky is still dark in order to prepare their equipment to fish in and around the Tunle Sap River, which is the best place to catch fish. After they have finished fishing, they take the fish and sell it at the local fish market. Besides fishing, Vet D. also provides a taxi service using his motorbike. Vet D. is requesting this loan to purchase a boat for his fishing business.

loans.use: To purchase a boat for his fishing business

loans.name: Liezel

texts.en:
Liezel O. is from the village of Batangan, Valencia City. She is 29 years old. Liezel is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Liezel owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling boiled duck eggs in the local community. Liezel has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5000 PHP per month for these activities. In 2009, Liezel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Liezel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Fozia Soria Group

texts.en:
This is Fozia Soria group, which includes four members. Soria is the group leader and has a bead working business in her house. She has run this business since the Taliban regime, when all women were confined to the home and there were no jobs and schools for them. Now, using the loan, she wants to buy more materials for her business to bring a change and progress to it. Soria wants to take out a loan to buy all the needed material which she needs for her business. She hopes that she will have a good business and high monthly income to support all of her family members.

Shafiqa wants a loan to use for her embroidery work. She mostly designs the national clothes that we call Afghani clothes.
Khanm G. wants to take out a loan for her husband who has a second hand clothes selling business. Khanm G.’s husband is a hard working man and through his shop’s income supports his family members.
Fozia wants to take out a loan for her husband who has a metal shop. Fozia’s husband is a hard working man and tries to have a comfortable life and educated children, and through the loan Fozia’s husband wants to expand his business and buy some essential tools which can make his work easier.

They have requested a group of loan 40000 Afghani. They are very happy with this global loan process in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Gen Tic Women’S Group Auma Doreen

texts.en: Doreen A. is a 29 year old business lady. She is married and the mother of five children, three of whom are schooling and looking after one dependant. She has been in the charcoal business for four years. She is in need of capital and is requesting this loan to purchase 30 bags of charcoal or more. Doreen plans to work very hard and hopes to educate her children.

loans.use: To add capital by purchasing 30 bags of charcoal or more

loans.name: Mellianita

texts.en: Mellianita M. is from the village of Sugarland, Valencia City. She is 45 years old, is widowed, and has four adult children. Mellianita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Mellianita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sharifa Jan Group

texts.en:
This is the Sharifa jan group. This group is made up of four members: Mashgan, Rowna, Naeida and Sharifa. Mashgan, who is in the middle, is the group leader. She is 40 years old and is married with four children, two sons and two daughters. She wants to take out a loan for a tailoring business. Since the Taliban regime, she has sewn clothes because her family has had lots of economic problems. Now, using the Kiva loan, she wants to buy a new sewing machine and wants to start her business as a new way of supporting her husband and children. 

Rowna is the second member of this group. She wants to take out a loan for her husband who has a car part shop. Rowna's husband wants to buy some tools which he still needs. This is the only business which they run with a six member family.

Naeida wants to take out a loan for her husband who has a bakery. Naeida's husband wants to buy all the needed materials for his business.

Sharifa wants to take out a loan for her husband who has a Therm (public bathhouse).  Sharifa's husband wants to buy more wood for his Therm. 

They have requested a group of loan 40000 Afghani. They would like to say lots of thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Expanding their businesses

loans.name: Ambe

texts.en:
M. is married but not living with her husband. She has two children. She lives in mile 2 of Nkwen-Cameroon.  M. and her entire family are living in a house with five rooms. M. has had to overcome some challenges in life, such as caring for her children, especially as she is separated from her husband. She is the one to pay school fees for her children. She has also had to cope with the death of her father and ill health.

M. sells drinks and food. She plans to invest this loan in the purchase of drinks, crates, pots, dishes, groundnuts and plantains.  

This will be M.'s fifth time to receive a loan from GHAPE. She has been a member since 2003. She has been quite successful in the past with her business due to the location of her business and her reasonable prices.  Also with experience, she is now experiencing good profits from her business.  Part of her profits from this loan will be used to take care of her children, to buy necessities for the family and give them good medication whenever they are sick; she will invest the rest of her profits in her business.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Top purchase drinks, crates, plates, spoons and trays

loans.name: Maria Njeri

texts.en:
Maria is 31 years old and married with one child. She owns a general store in Kwambira shopping center in Limuru where most of her clients are located. She has been in business for about ten years and has been earning a profit of 15,000 Kenya shillings per month.

She has never borrowed from another MFI before and she wants to use the loan to add to her store inventory with wheat flour, maize flour, and some cereals. Maria hopes to own a wholesale shop in the future.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add inventory

loans.name: Isioma

texts.en:
Isioma, 52, is a widow with seven children. She takes care of her children alone. She sells loaves of bread at retail prices to her customers. The demand for her bread is high in the mornings. She lives in Asaba, Delta State, Nigeria. She has been in this business for a long time. 

She hopes for a loan in the amount of 80,000 NGN to purchase more loaves of bread to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more loaves of bread to sell

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en:
Alfred S. M. is single and has four children. He has received technical education. Alfred sells premix fuel for fishermen at Elmina near Bantama, which he has been doing since 2002. Alfred uses his income to pay school fees, utility bills and general upkeep of the home.  

Alfred will use the loan to purchase more premix fuel for resale. With the new profits from his expanded business, Alfred plans to save and reinvest.

loans.use: To purchase more feul for resale

loans.name: Neba

texts.en:
J. is married with four children. He lives in Ntabesi-Nkwen, Cameroon. J. and his entire family are living in a house with four rooms. J. has had to overcome some challenges in life such as ill health, facing difficulties to pay his children's school fees and the death of his mother. He does carpentry work as his main profession and he wants to include a grocery store in his business.   

This will be J.'s fifth time to receive a loan from GHAPE. He has been a member since 2003. He has been quite successful in the past with his business due to the location of his workshop and his reasonable prices.  Also with experience, he is now seeing good profits from his business. Part of his profits from this loan will be used to take care of his children, buy necessities for the family and give them good medication whenever they are sick; he will invest the rest of the profits into his business.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase items for carpentry and a grocery store

loans.name: Chizoba

texts.en: Chizoba is 32 years old and married with three children. She sells cosmetics and supplies at retail prices to her customers. She lives in Asaba, Delta State, Nigeria. She is a hard working woman. She hopes for a loan in the amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more cosmetics and supplies to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics for resale

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. is married and has three children. She has been through junior high school. Mary sells fresh fish and gari (food item made from cassava tubers) at Mpoben near Elmina, which she has been doing since 1989. Her husband is a fisherman. Mary uses her income to support the husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.

Mary will use the loan to buy fish and gari for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to save and reinvest.

loans.use: To buy fish and gari for resale

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en: Blessing has a grocery stall where she sells groceries at retail prices to her customers. She is a friendly and hard working woman. She hopes to own a supermarket and a boutique in the future. She is 36 years old and married with seven children. She hopes for a loan in the amount of 80,000 NGN to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Muma

texts.en:
W. is a widow with three children. She lives in Foncha St, Nkwen, Cameroon. W. and her entire family are living in a house with two rooms. W. has had to overcome some challenges in life, such as ill health, facing difficulties to pay her children's school fees and the death of her husband. She does knitting and farming for a living.

This will be W.'s second time to receive a loan from GHAPE. She has been a member since 2008. She has been quite successful in the past with her business due to the location of her business and her reasonable prices.  Also with experience, she is now seeing good profits from her business. Part of her profits from this loan will be used to take care of her children, buy necessities for the family and give them good medication whenever they are sick and to buy some kitchen equipment.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its client

loans.use: To buy seeds and clear farmland; also to buy thread for knitting

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth A. sells grocery items, such as soap, washing powder, canned beef and tomatoes, at Elmina near Mpoben station. Elizabeth has a senior high education. She is single and cares for five dependents. Elizabeth has been selling groceries since 1987. She is responsible for paying school fees, utility bills and general upkeep of the home. 

Her loan will be used to buy more groceries for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save and reinvest.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items for resale

loans.name: Antonet

texts.en:
Selling groceries is the business activity from which Antonet makes a living. She is 33 years old and married with four children. She sells groceries at retail prices to her customers in her community of Asaba, Delta state, Nigeria. She has been in this business for a long time. 

She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for resale

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua A. is married and cares for five dependents. She has received vocational training. Efua sells corn mill plates and other spare parts at Elmina near Liverpool school, which she has been doing since 1996. Her husband is a driver.

Efua uses her income to support her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Efua will use the loan to purchase corn mill plates and spare parts for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Efua plans to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase corn mill plates and spare parts for resale

loans.name: Obinna

texts.en:
Obinna is 35 years old and married with five children. Her husband is a contractor. 

Obinna sells groceries and food items. She is so happy because of her Kiva loan. She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more groceries and food items to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and food items

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth Q. sells various kinds of fresh fish at Elmina seashore. Elizabeth has a senior high education. She is single and has four children. 

Elizabeth has been selling fresh fish since 1971. She is responsible for paying school fees, utility bills and general upkeep of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more fish for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest.

loans.use: To buy more fish for resale

loans.name: Ifeanyi

texts.en:
Ifeanyi is 34 years old and married with one child. Her child is in school. Her husband is a government worker. 

Ifeanyi is a member of LAPO. She sells groceries at retail prices to her customers. Ifeanyi is very hardworking and she makes sure that she has food on the table for her family. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She hopes for a loan amount of 80,000 NGN to purchase more groceries. She thanks all her Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Ifeoma

texts.en: Ifeoma is a focused, hard worker. She puts in long hours trying to keep her business sustainable. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers.  She sells sarongs, children clothes and bathing soap at retail prices in Asaba, Delta state, Nigeria.  She is 32 years old and married with three children. She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Rechel

texts.en:
Rechel V. is from the village of Panalsalan Plaridel Misamis Occidental. She is 24 years old. Rechel is married. To make a living, Rechel owns and operates a fishing business, selling seafood to local community members. Rechel has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month.

In 2009, Rechel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rechel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,500 PHP from GDMPC. Rechel is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Rechel from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Ifeoma

texts.en:
Ifeoma sells groceries and food items at retail prices to her customers. With the combined businesses, she is able to support her parents. She is excited about the high season and she hopes to make more sales during and after the season. She is 29 years old and single, without children. 

She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more groceries and food to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and food for resale

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en:
Rogelio G. is from the village of Panalsalan Plaridel Misamis Occidental. He is 54 years old. Rogelio is married and has two school-age children. To make a living, Rogelio owns and operates a business manufacturing and selling bamboo products to local businesses and community members. Rogelio has been in business for over 20 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Rogelio joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rogelio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC. Rogelio is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional raw materials to expand his product offerings. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Rogelio from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional raw materials to expand his product offerings

loans.name: Perla

texts.en:
Perla B. is from the town of Calaran, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 51 years old. Perla is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Perla sells food and other delicacies in the local community. Perla has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Perla joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Perla has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase items for resale. Perla is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional items to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Perla from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional purchase for food vending

loans.name: Gen Tic Women’S Group Atim Joyce

texts.en:
A. Joyce is twenty-three years old, married, and blessed with four children of whom two are going to school. She is also caring for five dependents, all schooling, too.

Joyce runs a stationery business and she has been doing this business for over five months. She is requesting the loan to purchase stationery items such as books, pens, files, papers, etc., to sell. She wants to improve upon her business at least for more profits.

Joyce is a hardworking business lady and her dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase stationery items such as books, pens, files, papers, etc.

loans.name: Dembagnouman Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Dembagnouman est composé de sept femmes dont une veuve et six  mariées dans des ménages polygames. Elles ont en moyenne 40 ans, 4 enfants et habitent dans le quartier Djaka (Kirango) de Markala (4ème Région administrative du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage, d’amitié et de voisinage. Elles ont comme  activités génératrices de revenus l’achat vente du poisson et sa transformation. 
Dans le souci de satisfaire ses clients le groupe Dembagnouman a décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son 5ème  prêt solidaire après avoir bien remboursé les quatre prêts précédents.
Ce nouveau prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter, 72 paniers de poisson frais et 100 barres  de glace (fournies par les transporteurs venant de Bamako). Elles s’approvisionnent  en poissons sur place au bord du fleuve Niger dont une bonne partie est séchée soit sur du gravier, ou sur de la paille ou sur des « seccos ». Le poisson frais est vendu sur place à Kirango et à Diamarabougou Markala ou  conservé dans de la glace pour être vendu à Ségou (au marché château) et à Bamako. Le poisson séché est conservé en partie jusqu’à la décrue et à l’hivernage où elles gagnent plus d’argent et le reste est vendu à Dougabougou, Siribala, N., Shango, Boussin et à la foire hebdomadaire de Ségou. Le poisson fumé est essentiellement vendu à Ségou. Les  ventes se font généralement au comptant à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
 Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice  moyen mensuel de 75.500 FCFA qui servira à satisfaire les petits besoins familiaux et à participer aux évènements sociaux (baptême, mariage et décès). 
Leur ambition est  d’acheter des animaux afin de construire dans l’avenir pour  leurs enfants car une maison paternelle appartient à tous et n’est propriété de personne.
texts.en:
The seven members of Dembagnouman Group (one widowed and six married women), on average, are 40 years old and have four children. They live in polygamous families in the neighborhood of Djaka (Kirango) in Markala, fourth administrative region of Mali. The group members know each other through links of family, marriage, friendship and neighborhood. They make a living from buying, processing and selling fish. Eager to better serve its customers, the Dembagnouman Group has decided to join the credit program offered by SoroYiriwaso. This is the Group's fifth solidarity loan, after having repaid the previous four loans on schedule.

This new loan will be used to buy 72 baskets of fresh fish and 100 ice bars, provided by carriers coming from Bamako. They get their fish supply on the banks of River Niger, then they dry part of it on gravel, on straw or on "seccos". The fresh fish will be sold on location in Kirango and in Diamarabougou Markala, or kept refrigerated in ice and sold at the Castle Market in Ségou and in Bamako. The dried fish will partly be stockpiled until the water level of the river drops in winter and they can sell it at a higher price, and partly be sold in Dougabougou, Siribala, N., Shango and Boussin, as well as at the weekly market in Ségou. They also sell smoked fish, mainly in Ségou. Most of their sales are for cash to a clientele made up of women and men.

They expect to make an average monthly profit of 75,500 CFA francs which they will spend on small household expenses and use to take part in social events (baptisms, weddings and funerals). Their ambition is to buy livestock so as to build houses for their children in future, because their father's house belongs to them all and nobody has the ownership of it.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fish

loans.name: Djiguifa Group

texts.fr:
Djiguifa est un regroupement de femmes toutes mariées, vivant majoritairement dans des grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 31 ans, 3 enfants et habitent  le quartier Djaka (Kirango) de Markala (4ème Région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage, d’amitié et exercent la même  activité génératrice de revenus à savoir l’achat vente du poisson sous ses diverses formes (frais, séché, fumé, frit etc.)
Le groupe Djiguifa est à son 5ème prêt solidaire, après avoir bien remboursé les quatre précédents avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.
Elles comptent utiliser ce nouveau prêt pour acheter, 72 paniers de poisson frais et 100 barres  de glace (fournies par les transporteurs venant de Bamako). Elles s’approvisionnent  en poisson frais sur place au bord du fleuve Niger. Tandis qu’une bonne partie de ce poisson est séchée soit sur du gravier soit sur de la paille ou sur des « seccos », l’autre partie est vendue sous toutes les formes: les poissons frais se vendent sur place à Kirango et à Diamarabougou Markala, le frais  conservé dans de la glace se vend à Ségou (au marché château) et Bamako, le poisson séché dont une partie est conservée jusqu’à la décrue et à l’hivernage où elles gagnent plus d’argent  est surtout vendu à Dougabougou, Siribala, Niono, Shango, Boussin et à la foire hebdomadaire de Ségou, le poisson fumé est essentiellement vendu à Ségou. Les ventes se font généralement au comptant, sur place au bord du fleuve, aux marchés de Kirango et de Diamarabougou (Markala) ou en ambulant à travers les quartiers du village à une  clientes diverse et variée.
Elles estiment pouvoir réaliser un bénéfice  moyen mensuel de 60.100 FCFA qui servira à satisfaire les petits besoins familiaux et à participer aux évènements sociaux. 
Leur ambition est  d’acheter des animaux afin de construire dans l’avenir pour soi et pour les enfants car une maison paternelle appartient à tous et n’est propriété de personne.
texts.en:
Djiguifa is an association of women who are all married and in large traditional families.  The women average 31 years of age and 3 children each living in the Djaka district (Kirango) of Markala (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They know one another through ties of kinship, marriage, and friendship, and they operate in the same revenue-generating business, namely the buying and selling fish in all its various forms (fresh, dried, smoked, fried, etc.) The group members are on their fifth solidarity loan after having repaid the four previous ones with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.  They intend to use this new loan to buy 72 baskets of fresh fish and 100 bars of ice (furnished by transporters coming from Bamako).  Supplies of fresh fish are gotten locally on the banks of the Niger River.  While a good portion of this fish is dried (whether on gravel or on straw or on seccos), the other portion is sold in any of its forms:  The fresh fish is sold locally in Kirango and in Diamarabougou Markala. The fresh fish kept on ice is sold in Ségou (at the Château Market) and Bamako.  The dried fish (part of which is reserved until the waters recede and until the off-season when the women earn more money) is sold especially in Dougabougou, Siribala, Niono, Shango, Boussin, and at the weekly fair of Ségou.  The smoked fish is essentially sold in Ségou.   Sales are made generally in cash to a diversity of customers locally along the river, at the marketplaces of Kirango and Diamarabougou (Markala), or door-to-door through the districts of the village. The group members think they'll be able to realize an average monthly profit of 60,100 francs CFA that will be used to cover sundry family needs and to assist with societal events.  Their ambition is to buy animals in order to build a future for themselves and their children, since a paternal home belongs to everyone but is not the property of anyone.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fish

loans.name: Lacen Kome Tek Atuko Rose Group

texts.en: Rose A., a 30-year-old married mother of three children attending school, deals with used clothes and shoes. She has been conducting this business for over five years and is now requesting a loan to purchase more stocks of used clothes and shoes to expand her enterprise. Rose is an active and promising lady who hopes to complete her house in the near future.

loans.use: To purchase more stocks of used clothes and shoes to expand her business.

loans.name: Babacar

texts.fr:
Babacar D. est un ancien sociétaire de la caisse de Baye Laye.Il vient de rembourser son quatrième crédit. Il est très connu par son dévouement et son dynamisme dans ses activités.
C’est un homme marie qui a quatre enfants dont l’âge varie entre huit mois et huit ans. Il a aussi quatre personnes en charge. Avant d’être commerçant il a été pendant quinze ans menuisier ébéniste un métier qu’il avait choisi par amour. Ensuite il a tente de gère un telecentre .Depuis deux ans il est spécialisé dans la vente de denrées alimentaires. Le commerce étant une activité qui lui rapporte beaucoup il sollicite un crédit de trois cent cinquante mille frs pour renforcer son capital et augmenter son stock de marchandise pour mieux faire face a la demande croissante de s veilles de fête.Son objectif est de diversifier ses produits renforcer son épargne et mieux satisfaire ses besoins personnels.
texts.en:
Babacar D. is a former member of the branch office of Baye Laye.  He just repaid his fourth loan.  He is well-known for dedication and dynamism in his work.  He is married and has four children, aged 8 months to 8 years.  He also has four people to support.  Before becoming a merchant, he was a furniture-maker working in ebony for fifteen years.  It's a trade he chose out of love.  Next he tried running a telecentre.  For two years, he has been specializing in selling food items. Commerce being work that brings in a lot for him, he's requesting a loan of 350,000 francs for bolstering his capital and for increasing his stock of merchandise in order to cope with the growing demand as the holidays approach.  His goals are to diversify his goods, to boost his savings, and to meet his personal requirements further. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster his working capital

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Friendly and happy, Charity, a 37-year-old married mother of seven children, sells clothes of various colors and baby things.  She is determined to lift her business and family above poverty, but the foremost challenge she faces is losing customers to competitors because she cannot meet demand. Charity has been in this business for a long time and hopes for a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more clothes and baby things to sell.  She says thanks to all who make the loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and baby things to sell

loans.name: Nyetaa Group

texts.fr:
Les membres  du Nyetaa sont au nombre de quatre femmes,  toutes mariées dans des foyers monogames,  ayant en moyenne 29 ans, 3 enfants, elles habitent  le quartier Djaka (Kirango)  de Markala (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage, d’amitié et  sont membres d’une même association traditionnelle « Traoré Ton » qui donna son nom  à leur actuelle association. Elles font presque toutes la même activité à savoir  l’achat et la vente du poisson sous diverses formes  (frit, séché, fumé, frais etc.)
Le groupe Nyetaa est à son 5ème prêt de groupe, après avoir bien remboursé les quatre précédents prêts sans aucune difficulté.
Ce nouveau prêt servira à utiliser, 40 paniers de poisson frais, 12 barres  de glace.  Elles s’approvisionnent  en poissons frais sur place au bord du fleuve Niger. Une bonne partie de ce poisson est séchée soit sur du gravier soit sur de la paille ou sur des « seccos ».Le reste du poisson se vend sous toutes les formes : les poisson frais   se vendent sur place à Kirango et à Diamarabougou Markala, le frais  conservé dans de la glace se vend à Ségou ( au marché château) et  Bamako, le poisson séché dont une partie est conservée jusqu’à la décrue où elles gagnent plus d’argent  est surtout vendu à Dougabougou, Siribala, Niono, Shango, Boussin et à la foire hebdomadaire de Ségou, le fumé est essentiellement vendu à Ségou. Les ventes se font généralement au comptant à une  clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes, sur place au bord du fleuve, aux marchés de Kirango et de Diamarabougou (Markala) ou en ambulant à travers les quartiers du village. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice  moyen mensuel de 52.800 FCFA qui servira à satisfaire les petits besoins familiaux  et  à participer aux évènements sociaux. 
Leur ambition est d’avoir une concession  à travers l’épargne en animaux pour les enfants.
texts.en:
The Nyetaa Group consists of four women, all of whom are married and living in monogamous relationships. They have an average age of 29 and an average of three children each. They live in the Djaka (Kirango) neighborhood in Markala (in the fourth administrative region of Mali). The women met through family ties, marriage and friendships, and they are all members of the same traditional association, "Traoré Ton", from which they have taken the name of their current association. They all have the same business activity: buying and selling fish in various forms (fried, dried, smoked, fresh etc.). The Nyetaa Group is on its fifth group loan, having paid back the four previous loans with no problems. This new loan will allow them to purchase 40 baskets of fresh fish and 12 blocks of ice. They stock up on fresh fish locally, on the banks of the Niger River. A good portion of this fish is dried, either on stones, straw or "seccos". The rest is sold in different ways: the fresh fish is sold locally in Kirango and Diamarabougou Markala; the fresh fish conserved on ice is sold in Ségou (at the castle market) and Bamako; the dried fish, some of which is kept until the waters recede when it is worth more, is mostly sold in Dougabougou, Siribala, Niono, Shango, Boussin and at the weekly fair in Ségou; the smoked fish is mainly sold in Ségou. The sales are generally transacted in cash to a clientele made up of both men and women, and are carried out locally beside the river, in the Kirango or Diamarabougou (Markala) markets or door-to-door in village. The women expect to make an average monthly profit of 52,800 FCFA, which will allow them to take care of some small family needs and to participate in social events. Their ambition is to save enough money to buy their children a plot of land on which to raise animals.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fish

loans.name: Gene Keni Achola Hellen Group

texts.en:
A. Hellen is forty-nine years of age; she is a widow and treasurer of her group. She is blessed with six children, all schooling.

Hellen runs the business of purchasing cereals, that is: maize, which she has been doing so far for three years. She is requesting the loan to raise the stock of her business by purchasing at least seven or more bags of maize.

Hellen is a courageous businesswoman whose dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase at least seven or more bags of maize

loans.name: Barta

texts.en:
Barta N. makes a living selling groundnut paste, tomatoes and other items, and has applied for this loan to buy fresh cassava and maize to sell.  She is 30 years old and married to a policeman. They have four children, all of whom go to school. With the extra profits made possible by this loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to buy fresh cassava and maize to sell

loans.name: Obiagah

texts.en: Obiagah is 25 years old and married. She has no children at present, but hopes to raise a family in the future. Obiagah is a focused, hard-working woman and is happy to sell fruit for a living because it gives her a chance to spend a lot of time with her customers. She hopes to be a major fruit distributor in her community of Asaba, Delta state. To help make this possible, she has applied for a loan for N80,000. She will use this money to buy more fruit to sell, and offers thanks to all Kiva lenders for their assistance.

loans.use: To buy more fruit to sell

loans.name: Naome

texts.en:
Naome J. makes a living selling bread and charcoal, and has applied for this loan to buy more charcoal to sell.  She is 32 years old  and married to a builder. They have five children, all of whom are in school.  With the extra income made possible by this loan, she hopes to increase her store of charcoal.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Sabougnouman Group

texts.fr:
Les huit membres du groupe Sabougnouman sont tous des femmes mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogames. Elles ont en moyenne 31 ans, 4 enfants et  habitent  le quartier Djaka (Kirango)  de  Markala (4ème Région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ce groupe est uni par des liens de parenté, de mariage, d’amitié, de voisinage et est membres de l’association traditionnelle « Traoré Ton » qui donna son nom  à leur actuelle association. Elles ont comme activité la vente du poisson sous diverses formes.  
Sabougnouman est un groupe qui collabore avec Soro Yiriwaso et  qui est à son 5ème prêt solidaire, après avoir bien remboursé les précédents. 
Ce nouveau prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter, 10 paniers de poisson frais et 50 barres  de glace (fournies par les transporteurs venant de Bamako). Elles s’approvisionnent  en poissons frais sur place au bord du fleuve Niger. Une bonne partie de ce poisson est séchée soit sur du gravier soit sur de la paille ou sur des « seccos ».Le poisson se vend sous toutes les formes : les poissons frais  se vendent sur place au bord du fleuve, à Kirango et à Diamarabougou Markala dans les foires ou en ambulant dans les quartiers, le frais  conservé dans de la glace se vend à Ségou  (au marché château), une partie du poisson séché est conservée jusqu’à l’hivernage où elles gagnent plus d’argent et est surtout revendu dans les foires de Dougabougou, Siribala, Boussin et Ségou Les ventes se font généralement au comptant à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 37.000 FCFA qui servira à satisfaire les petits besoins familiaux. 
Leur ambition est  d’acheter et d’élever des animaux afin de construire dans l’avenir leurs propres maisons.
texts.en:
The eight members of the Sabougnouman group are all married women, the majority in monogamous families. On average they are 31 years old with 4 children and live in the Djaka (Kirango) neighborhood of Markala (4th administrative Region of the republic of Mali). This group is united by bonds of kinship, marriage, friendship, and neighborhood. They are members of the traditional "Traoré Ton" association that gave its name to their current association. Their activity is the sale of fish in various forms. Sabougnouman is a group that collaborates with Soro Yiriwaso and that is on its 5th loan, after having repaid the preceding ones well. This new loan will be used to buy 10 baskets of fresh fish and 50 blocks of ice (furnished by the carriers coming from Bamako). They supply themselves with fresh fish on the spot by the river Niger. A good part of this fish is dried on gravel, on straw or on one of the "dryers". The fish is sold in various ways: the fresh fish are sometimes sold on the spot by the river, in Kirango and in Diamarabougou Markala in the market or on foot in the neighborhoods. The fresh fish is packed in ice and sold in Ségou (in the market house). Part of the dried fish is preserved until winter, when they earn more money and is sold in the markets of Dougabougou, Siribala, Boussin and Ségou. They generally sell the fish themselves to a cash clientele composed of women and men. They hope to realize a monthly average profit of 37,000 FCFA that will serve to satisfy their small family needs. Their ambition is to buy and raise animals in order to construct their own houses in the future.

Translated from French by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fish and ice

loans.name: Dama

texts.en:
Dama O. makes a living selling bread and tea, and has applied for this loan to buy fresh fish to cook and sell. She is 26 years old and married. Her husband is a soldier and they have two children, both of whom are in school. With the extra profits made possible by this loan, she hopes to be able to open up a resturant in a good location.
