They are blessed with four children but three of them are already married and have their own families. Rexie, 2 years old, is the only one who lives with them.

Virginia manages their furniture shop in their village. The couple are striving hard for their family needs and she would like to develop her business in order for them to achieve success in life. Due to her many orders, she would like to ask for additional capital from Kiva lenders so that she can produce more furniture.

Virginia is asking for a loan of Php 5,000 which will allow her to buy the materials needed in her furniture business. With the loan she hopes that her business will become more progressive.

loans.use: To buy materials for her furniture-making business

loans.name: Do

texts.en:
Do S., 39, is married with three children. She resides in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia with her husband (pictured) and children.

To make a living, her husband provides transportation services by operating his motorbike with the compartment attached, earning approximately an income of $8.50 USD per day. The family is also assisted by one of her children, who is currently employed as a security guard at a local garment factory. He is able to earn an income of $3.00 USD per day to help cover the household expenses.

Mrs. S. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, Mrs. S. is asking for a loan of $1200 USD to purchase piglets to raise for resale.

loans.use: To buy piglets for resale in order to diversify her business.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn M. is 33 years old. She is married to a driver named Willie Sr., and they are blessed with four children: Edieber, 16, followed by Willie Jr., 13, Angelie, 8, and their youngest, Adrianne, who is five months old. They live in the small village of Santa Maria, Alicia, Isabela. Rice farming is one of the major sources of income in their village, and they only have a harvest season twice a year.

For almost one year now, Jocelyn has managed a typical retail store in her village. Her daily net income is 200 Philippine pesos (PHP). She is requesting a loan amount of 5,000 PHP from Kiva lenders, which she will use to purchase additional grocery items to sell.

According to Jocelyn, strong determination is one of the characteristics that one should develop in order to run a business that produces a bountiful income. She always gives her very best to improve her small general store.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery items for her store.

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Heng V., 61, is married with six children. Two of her children are still students at a local high school. She resides in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia with her husband and children.

To make a living, she is in business selling vegetables, earning an income of about $3.30 USD per day. The family is also assisted by her husband, who is currently engaged in business as a carpenter. He is able to earn an income of about 80 cents (USD) per day which supports the childrens’ studies and helps cover the household expenses.

Mrs. V. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, Mrs. V. is asking for a loan of $550 USD to purchase a motorbike with a trailer attached in order to more easily transport vegetables to the market.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike with a trailer attached.

loans.name: Precy

texts.en:
Vending of snacks is what makes Precy B. busy. Precy is 23 years old and married to Eldridge Sr. They are blessed with two children: Eldridge Jr., who is 2 years old and Eliezar Daniel, who is 1 year old. The family lives in the village of Aguinaldo, Cordon.

Precy would like to buy more merchandise to be able to generate a bigger income for her family needs, especially while her children are still young and still drinking expensive milk. For this reason, Precy would like to apply for a loan of 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) from Kiva lenders for her business development. Precy shared with us that with the loan and with her hard work she will eventually succeed. She just hopes that the lenders will grant her requested loan.

loans.use: To purchase additional capital for vending snacks business.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen N. is from the village of Palacapao, Quezon Bukidnon. She is 37 years old. Helen is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Helen owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Helen has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10,000 Philipppine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2007, Helen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Helen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Helen is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Helen from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is oe of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business.

loans.name: Shierly

texts.en:
Shierly M. is a very determined person. She manages a stall in their village where she displays some of her commodities. She sells fruit, vegetables, rice cakes and grocery items, and her daily net income is Php 200.

Shierly would like to expand her business and maintain the flow of productivity. She wants to obtain a loan from Kiva lenders of Php 7,000 as additional working capital for her business.

Shierly is married to a security guard named Joseph Sr., and the couple is blessed with four children namely: Mark Anthony, 20, followed by Jennifer, 17, Joseph Jr., 16, and Jonalyn, 4 years old. They live in the village of Sta. Maria, Alicia, Isabela, and their house is near the National Highway.

Shierly does her very best to increase their income and have a bountiful business income.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her grocery store

loans.name: Purificacion

texts.en:
Humility and sacrifice are the guiding principles of Purificacion R.. She is 54 years of age and married but she is still determined to improve their way of living through her variety store business. She dreams of expanding her store by asking for additional capital of Php 5,000 from Kiva lenders. She hopes that she will be able to obtain this loan for her family needs and for emergency purposes.

Purificacion has been blessed with eight children but two of them are already married and have their own families. Six of her children are still single and they are: Aileen - 29 years old, a college undergraduate; Georace King - 26 years old, a high school graduate; Garry - 22 years old, a high school graduate; Abegail - 20 years old; Gilbert - 16 years old; and Angela Marie - 9 years old, an elementary pupil.

Purificacion hopes that she will be able to continue to support the schooling of her youngest daughter.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for the expansion of her variety store

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok B., 28, is married with a young child. She resides in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia, with her husband (pictured with his father) and her child.

To make a living, B. is engaged in the business of opening a dental clinic in her home, earning an income of approximately US$3 per day. The family is also assisted by her husband who is a taxi driver, providing his transportation services in the province and from the province to the city. He is able to earn an income of US$2 per day to help cover the household expenses.

Mrs. B. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, B. is asking for a loan of US$800 to purchase supplements for her dental clinic.

loans.use: To buy supplements for her dental clinic

loans.name: Jeffrey

texts.en:
Jeffrey T. is 34 years old and he is married to Lanielyn, 32 years old, who works as a public teacher in their village. They are blessed with two children: Reynilyn - 11 years old, a grade IV pupil; and Andrey - 3 years old. Their family resides in the village of Larion Alto, Tuguegarao City.

Jeffrey is a tricycle operator and his weekly net income is PHP 500. He plans to obtain a loan of PHP 5,000 from Kiva lenders that will be used for the repair and maintenance of his motorcycle. He is also engaged in farming and hog raising businesses.

loans.use: To use for the repair and maintenance of his motorcycle

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina M. is from the village of Batangan,Valencia City. She is 47 years old. Rosalina is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Rosalina owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling fruit salad and  flavored icebars in the local community. Rosalina has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rosalina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalina is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase the raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Rosalina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Hog raising is the business of Mary Ann A.. She is 49 years old and is married to Anacleto A. Sr. They are thankful because they are blessed with eight children, two of whom are married. The single ones are: Arlene-21 years old who only finished grade-IV due to financial problems; also  Anabelle-18 years old who only finished 2nd year high school; Milbert-13 years old who  finished grade-IV; Anacleto Jr.-10 years old, a grade-III pupil ;Angelita-6 years old, and the youngest is Michelle-4 years old. Mary Ann and her husband work hard to support their family. 

Due to insufficient capital, Mary Ann is asking for additional capital from  KIVA lenders amounting to Php4,000 for the maintenance of her hog raising business.

loans.use: Additional capital for her hog raising business

loans.name: Khem

texts.en: Khem P., 53, is a widow with three children. She resides in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia with her children. To make a living, she is engaged in a business of selling fish at a local market in the town, earning approximately US $4 per day. The family is also assisted by her children who are currently employed at a local garment factory with a daily income of US $3 per day. And another child is working in a neighboring country, sending his money once every two months. Those sources of income from her children help cover the household expenses. Mrs. P. is seeking to improve her standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, Mrs. P. is asking for a loan of US $1200 to purchase a motorbike for one of her children to commute to work at the factory easily.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Aracelie

texts.en:
Aracelie M. is from the village of Valencia City. She is 39 years old. Aracelie is married and has 3 school-age children. To make a living, Aracelie owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Aracelie has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Aracelie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aracelie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Aracelie is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Aracelie from HSPFI. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Chom

texts.en: Chom S., 38, is married with four children. Two of her children are enrolled at a local high school. She resides in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia with her husband and children. To make a living, her husband is engaged in a business of providing transportation services in the town, earning  an income of approximately US$4 per day. Furthermore, he produces bread when he is available from his work in the day time. The family is also assisted by two of their children who are currently employed in a local garment factory. They partly help cover the household expenses. Mrs. S. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of US $600 to have his motorbike repaired so that he will be able to run his business efficiently. (Chom S. is pictured with her husband)

loans.use: To have the family motorbike repaired

loans.name: Carlito

texts.en: Carlito Laurito, Jr. is from the village of Mailag, Valencia City. He is 39 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Carlito owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Carlito joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be his first from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Saom

texts.en:
Saom T., age 57, is a modest villager living in Kampong Chhnang Province. She currently lives with her two teenage children and her husband, who stay at home to weave bamboo basket for sale.

To earn a living, Saom T. has owned a small handicraft business as a bamboo-basket weaver. She makes baskets and then and sells them to her buyer in bulk for a profit.

Saom T. lacks raw materials for her business so she requested a loan from Kiva in order to purchase more bamboo to make baskets.

loans.use: To purchase more bamboo to make baskets

loans.name: Mariejoy

texts.en:
“Achieving success in life is not that easy due to some instances you have to undergo,” said Mariejoy R.. She is married to Edgar R. who is engaged in their rice-farming business. Mariejoy and Edgar have been blessed with two children.

Mariejoy sells some snacks and at the same time she manages a hog-raising business to have an additional source of income. Mariejoy hopes that she will be able to maintain her businesses for them to generate a bigger income. Through her hog-raising and vending activity she is able to support the needs of her family.

Mariejoy hopes that she will be able to obtain a loan from Kiva lenders for the improvement and maintenance of her businesses. Thus, she is requesting a Php 5,000 loan. She hopes that she will be able to make her businesses more profitable.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her hog-raising business

loans.name: Lucita

texts.en: Lucita L. is from the village of Palacapao, Quezon, Bukidnon. She is 37 years old, is widowed, and has seven school-aged children. Lucita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Lucita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Lucita is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 6th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Or

texts.en:
Or V., age 54, lives in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. She has owned a plot of land since 1999. She grows both rice and vegetable crops. She plants her crops twice a year; once in the dry season and once in the raining season. Or V. is taking a loan to buy a piglet to raise.  

Or V. was married, but her husband died of senility. She has two children; one is married and the other one is a garment worker.

loans.use: To buy a piglet to raise

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana D. sells MSE and Natasha cosmetics. She is 58 years old and is still striving to earn a daily living. She is married to Rogelio D. and they are blessed with eleven children, six of whom are already married. 

Currently she is paying for the allowances, tuition fees, and projects of two of her children who are in high school. Susana wants these two children to finish their schooling because education is the only thing she can give to them. Therefore, Susana and her husband are striving hard to meet their family's needs, especially those of her two students. 

Susana can meet the needs of her children only with the help of her husband and her direct-sales business. But Susana still needs additional capital to buy additional products to sell. Thus, she has decided to borrow Php5,000 from KIVA lenders. She knows that her determination to improve her family's living conditions will lead her to success.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Suon

texts.en:
Mr. Suon S., 28, is an internal administrator for an organization. He is married to Soy Sopha, age 28, who earns a living by selling and renting CDs to the villagers from her home. Her business can contribute $4.50 a day to their living expenses. The couple has one teenage child who attends school. Suon S. will use his loan to expand his wife's CD business. 

Note: Mrs. Soy Sopha appears in the photograph, because Mr. Suon S. was not available at the time.

loans.use: To expand his wife's CD business

loans.name: Mercedita

texts.en:
Mercedita G. is from the village of Bagontaas in Valencia City. She is 38 years old. Mercedita is married and has 1 school-aged children. To make a living, Mercedita sells herbal products, including herbal food supplements, in the local community. Mercedita has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Mercedita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mercedita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Mercedita's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena G. was born in Larion Alto in Tuguegarao City. She is happily married to Melchor G., who is a local laborer in their village. They are blessed with two children; Abigail, age 16, who is a first year college student studying Information Technology and Claribel, age 15, who is a senior high school student.

Magdalena has a dressmaking business. She is 57 years old and she has been in this business for 30 years. Farming provides the income that supports the needs of their family. 

To help her husband meet the daily needs of their family, she started the business that she knows best. With God's help, she was able to start her sewing business which helps her to support the educational needs of her children. She now wants to borrow PHP 5,000 to maintain her business.

loans.use: Additional capital for her sewing business

loans.name: Vong

texts.en:
Mr. S. was born in 1974. His wife, Sor Mom, is 30 years old. They live together in Kampong Chhnang Province. This couple was married many years ago and they have four school-aged children. Mr. S. is a goldsmith. His wife stays sells groceries to neighbors from their home.They typically earn an average of $5 per day, which they use to better meet their family's financial needs. 

S. has been working as a goldsmith for a long time, but his business still requires more material. Thus, he decided to seek a loan to buy extra equipment for his business.

loans.use: To buy extra equipment for his goldsmithing business

loans.name: Relita

texts.en:
Relita A. is a resident of Barangay Marcos in Roxas, Isabela. She is a loving mother of four children. Relita is married to Apolonio, Sr,, a farmer. Farming is their main source of income, but they only earn money from farming during the harvest season. Thus, Relita decided to raise pigs for extra  income and her husband took a job working in their neighbor's farm whenever he is not busy in their own farm.

Because she lacks the necessary capital, Relita has decided to borrow Php 5,000 from Kiva lenders to buy feed for her pigs. She hopes that KIVA lenders will grant her requested loan.

loans.use: To buy pig feed

loans.name: Penh

texts.en:
S. O., age 37, is a widowed mother of three school-aged children. In the beginning of 2000, S. O. built a small store in front of her home. In her shop, she sells a few grocery items to the neighbors who live near her house in the village. Her children help her to sell groceries. 

In addition, she always has one pig that she is raising. She keeps the pig in a stall next to her house. Although she has sold her mature pig, she doesn't have the money to buy another, so she is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase piglet to raise.

loans.use: To purchase piglet to raise

loans.name: Hak

texts.en:
Hak C., age 53, is married and has four children. One of her children is enrolled at the local high school. She resides in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia with her husband (pictured) and children. To make a living, C. and her husband have a blacksmith business. They can earn approximatelyUS $20 per day. The parents are assisted by two of their children who are currently employed in a local garment factory and earn a daily income of US $3.50. They partly help cover the household expenses. 

Mrs. C. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, C. is asking for a loan of US $1200 to purchase more metal to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more metal

loans.name: Ben

texts.en:
S. is a low-income person who live in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. To earn a living, S. makes clay pots. She also provides decorating services for wedding parties. She is a good mother who is blessed with three children. Her husband is a military policeman. 

S. needs some money to buy larger quantities of decorating material. To continue to provide good service, she has decided to ask for a loan to buy more equipment for her business.

loans.use: To buy equipment for her decorating business

loans.name: Mam

texts.en:
Mam M. is 36 years old and a resident of Kampong Chhnang Province. She earns a living raising ducks in a cage behind her house. She raises the ducks to produce eggs and then she sells the eggs to people who come to her house to buy in bulk. She is married and has five children who attend the local public school. Her husband, Chan Lin, works with her in the business. 

Mam M. has applied for a loan from HKL, a Kiva field partner, to purchase additional feed and ducks to raise.

loans.use: To purchase additional feed and ducks to raise

loans.name: Men

texts.en: Men P. is a 30-year-old married man who is blessed with five teenage children. Four of the children are employed in a garment factory. Men P. currentlysells a few produce items from his small store in front of his home. His wife is a rice farmer and also a good homemaker who cooks tasty meals for the family. Recently, Men P.'s business has been very busy because there are many clients who need to buy his produce, but he doesn't have enough items to sell to his customers. Therefore, he would like to request a loan to buy more groceries to sell.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Kim H., age 40, is married and has three children. Two of her children are enrolled in the local high school. She resides in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia with her husband and children. To make a living, H. and her husband sell fried noodles. Together, they can earn an income of approximately US $24 per day . Mrs. Chheng and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, Chheng is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase supplies to expand her fried noodle business.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for their fried noodle business

loans.name: Yay

texts.en:
Yay K. was born in 1970. She is a married woman who is blessed with four children. All of her children are students in the local public school. Her husband, Sophal, age 36, is a community medical doctor. 

Yay K. has built a stall behind her house where she raises chickens to earn a living. In addition, she always cultivates a rice crop. Yay K. is a a loan to pay the cost of building a restroom for her family.

loans.use: To build a restroom for her family

loans.name: Chhom

texts.en: Chhom C., age 34, is married and has three children. Two of her children are enrolled in the local school. To make a living, she designs and sews clothing. She earns an income of US $4.00 per day. The family is also assisted by her husband, a taxi driver in Kampot Province, who earns US $4.50 per day as the primary source of income for the family. C. and her husband are seeking to improve his business and their family's standard of living. Therefore, she is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase a new sewing machine to expand her sewing business.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Anabella

texts.en:
Anabella is married to Mr. Fernando F., who is a farmer. Anabella has a poultry business. She raises chicken and ducks in their village of San Pedro, Roxas, Isabela. Her husband manages their small farm. Sometimes she also helps her husband to maintaining their farm.

Anabella needs additional capital to maintain her poultry. She dreams of expanding her business to provide another source of income for their family. She wanted to save money little by little for the future of her children. Thus, she is requesting a loan of Php 6,000 from Kiva lenders for her poultry business. She hopes that her requested loan will be granted because it will really help to improve her business.

loans.use: Additional capital for her poultry business

loans.name: Arnel

texts.en:
“If you work, you will live. If you have patience, you will succeed.” This a word of encouragement shared by Mr. Arnel C. of Barangay Curifang in Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. He is married to Mrs.Vicky C. and they are blessed with two children, Aji C. and Amiel C.. The eldest is now in secondary school while the youngest is in elementary school. The parents endure hardships and difficulty to earn a living for the sake of their children.

As a way of gaining income,  Arnel uses his jeepney to provide taxi services. His wife has chosen to work as an Overseas Filipino Worker (OFW) in Malaysia. Arnel earns a net income of Php 300 daily, which he uses to provide for their basic needs and the needs of their children. Since his income is not sufficient to meet their daily needs, he wants to borrow Php 5,000 from Kiva lenders to repair his jeepney so that he can use it every day.  He hopes that, with this financial assistance, his daily income will increase.

loans.use: To repair his jeepney

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mr. Mao N., age 26, is married and has a lovely young child. Mao N. shares responsibility for his family by working in construction. His wife is a garment worker. Mao N. is looking for a loan to purchase piglets to raise for additional income. The new business that he starts with this loan will provide his family with a better standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase piglet to raise

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok S., age 29, is single and lives with her sister. To make a living, she designs and sews clothes. She earns US $10.00 per day. Her income is the primary source of funds for her family. The family is also assisted by her sister, a hairdresser who earns US $4.00 per day. S. and her sister are seeking to improve their businesses and standard of living. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of US $700 to purchase fabric to design more clothes to sell to her new and existing customers.

loans.use: To buy fabric for her clothing design business

loans.name: Oeun

texts.en:
Mr. OeU. U. is 65 years old. He appears in the accompanying photograph with his son. OeU. is widower with 4 children, 1 son and 3 daughters. All of them are married and live outside the family home. OeU. lives along National Road Number One, about thirty-five kilometers from Phnom Penh.
 
OeU. has been a construction contractor for 50 years. He doesn’t have enough materials to operate his business, so he is asking for his first loan of $350 to purchase construction materials for his business.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials for his business.

loans.name: Domingo

texts.en:
Domingo Pangilinan, Jr. is also known as "Don-Don" in his village located at Barangay Bagahabag, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. He is now 31 years old and still single but he wants to help his siblings with their studies. Moreover, he also wants to be financially prepared before he gets married so that he can support his future family.

Don-Don operates his jeepney everyday from Solano to Bayombong and from Bayombong to Solano. According to him, he is able to earn a net income of Php 400 daily which he uses to acquire their basic needs and to support the schooling of his younger brothers and sisters.

Because of his interest in increasing his income, Don-Don applied for loan of Php 5,000 from Kiva lenders which he will use for the maintenance of his jeepney. He is looking forward to the approval of his requested loan.

loans.use: To use for the maintenance of his jeepney

loans.name: Yun

texts.en:
Mrs. Yun C., 45, and her husband, Mr. Phally Phal, 46, live in a small village across the Mekong River, about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1984 and have seven children: five sons - one is a monk, three attend school, and another one is a chef; and two daughters - one weaves silk at home.

Yun has been a silk weaver for three years while her husband is a fisherman. She doesn’t have enough capital to purchase silk materials for her weaving business, so she is requesting her first loan of US$300 to help her capital.

Yun hopes to supplement her income with a pig-raising business which would better enable her to earn income to support her family. Therefore, she will use a part of her loan to purchase piglets to raise.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her silk-weaving business and to buy piglets to raise

loans.name: Ayet

texts.en: Ayet M. is currently in the business of selling beer, bread and charcoal at home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Ayet is 22 years old and is married to a nurse. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a bar and a charcoal store. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Ratana

texts.en:
Miss Ratana T., 28, has been a silk weaver since 2007. It’s a skill she learned from her mother. She lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Ratana’s mother has been weaving silk and selling silk fabric since 1979. She buys the finished products from weavers in her village and sells them in other provinces far away from her house. She hopes to continue expanding her business.

Hence, Ratana is requesting a loan of $500 to help provide capital for her mother to purchase more finished silk fabrics for resale.

loans.use: To help provide capital for her mother to purchase more finished silk fabrics for resale

loans.name: Sour

texts.en: Sour R., 39, is married with three school-aged children. All of his children are enrolled at a local high school. He resides in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, with his wife (pictured) and children. To make a living, he is employed as a police officer in the city. He is able to earn an income of approximately US $6 per day as a primary source of income for his family. The family is also assisted by his wife, who is currently selling groceries at her home, with a daily income of US $5. Both sources of income help cover the household expenses. Mr. Sour R. and his wife are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, R. is asking for a loan of US $500 to purchase more groceries to stock his wife's shop.

loans.use: To buy groceries

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Mrs. Josefina R. is fifty years of age and from the village of San Pedro, Roxas, Isabela. She is engaged in the business of fattening pigs. At her age, she can still manage taking care of a number of pigs. She is doing this for her family, especially since she still has children who are attending school.  A few months ago she sold one of her raised animals because her child needs money for her school tuition fee. 

Josefina's only source of income is through her piggery, so she is really working hard, but due to financial constraints, she wants to borrow a Php 7,000 loan from Kiva lenders for the maintenance of her pigs and for feed. She is optimistic that her loan will be granted.

loans.use: Maintenance of her pigs and feed

loans.name: Son

texts.en:
Mrs. Son L., age 54, is a widow with three children: one son and two daughters. Two of them are married, one living in a separate home and the other one living in the family home. Another daughter assists her mother in the business. They live in a small village aL. National Road Number 2, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Son has been selling Cambodian cakes for five years. She buys ingredients from the market to make cakes by herself and sells them in her village.

Son hopes to supplement her income with another business raising cows; she will get more income from selling cows after they grow big enough. Therefore, she is requesting her first loan of $500 to purchase cows to raise. She will also use a part of her loan to buy sweet rice for producing Cambodian cakes to sell.

loans.use: To purchase cows to raise and to buy sweet rice

loans.name: Gune

texts.en: Gune J. is currently in the business of selling groundnut phaste (peanuts that have been ground or crushed into a paste), onions, tomatoes, etc., at the market and is requesting a loan to purchase chickens from Uganda to sell. Gune is 27 years old and is married to a businessman. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a hotel (restaurant) and a bakery. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase chickens from Uganda to sell

loans.name: Ny

texts.en:
Mrs. Ny S., 25 and her husband, Mr. Samnang Pouk, 28, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 2007 and just have a young son.

Ny has been a silk weaver since she was married and her husband is a silk weaver as well. Besides weaving he is also a farmer, growing many types of vegetables and other crops on his farmland near his village. They sell their finished products to the middleman in the village who then, in turn, sells them at the market located in Phnom Penh.

Ny is requesting a loan of US$250 to purchase silk materials to continue her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase more silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina J. sells goods like fish and onions and is requesting a loan to purchase beans and maize flour to sell.  Lina is 35 years old and is married with a husband that is a businessman. She has 6 children and they all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.  BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase beans and maize flour to sell

loans.name: Em

texts.en: Em N., 47, is a widow with two children. She resides in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia with her children. To make a living, she rents discs, earning approximately $5 US per day. This is her second loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. The family is also assisted by one of her children who is currently employed in a local garment factory. He helps cover the household expenses. Ms. N. and her children are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, N. is asking for a loan of $200 US to purchase more discs to rent and juice for sale.

loans.use: To buy discs and juice

loans.name: Som-Ol

texts.en:
Mrs. Som-ol C., 62, and her husband, Mr. Chheng Pong, 60, have been married for over thirty years. They have four children: three sons and one daughter. Their daughter is married and lives in a separate home, but two of their sons attend school and the other weaves silk at home. The family is living on an island of the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Som-ol has been a weaver for more than forty years. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village where she is living, who then resells them in Phnom Penh. Her husband, Mr. Chheng Pong, has been a farmer since 1960. Additionally, he also raises cows. 

Som-ol has asked for a loan from Kiva one time already. She is now requesting another loan of $100 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To buy silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: By

texts.en: By S. is married and lives with one young child. She works as a farmer in the Kampong Cham province, typically making $2 each day. She is supported by her husband, who works and sells land. Her husband needs to replace the old wheels, so the family would like a loan of $1,200 to purchase the wheels.

loans.use: To replace old wheels

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Saroeun S., 62, has been a silk weaver for over 47 year. She has been married Mr. Oeun Kim, 62, since 1973. They have six children: four sons and two daughters. Two of them are married and live outside the family home, while two sons are in school and one daughter is also a silk weaver. The family lives on an island of the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Saroeun is requesting her second loan of $150 to purchase silk materials for continuing her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for continuing her weaving business

loans.name: Monika

texts.en:
Monika G. is currently in the business of selling fish and beans at the market and is requesting a loan to purchase bags of rice to sell. Monika is 36 years old and married to a soldier. She has nine children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase bags of rice to sell

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
"Having many children is not easy. I need to double my time working if I’m to support all their needs, especially their education," said Erlinda S.. She is now 58 years of age and married to Mr. Benjamin S. who is a farmer and already 65 years old. The couple is blessed with eight children. Only one of them is still studying.

Erlinda sells her vegetables and fruit in their village, roaming around the village by going house to house. Though her business is tiring, she does not mind it because she knows that she needs to become strong if she is to succeed.

In connection with that, Erlinda wants to borrow Php 7,000 from Kiva lenders as additional capital for her vending business. If her requested loan is granted, she will buy more vegetables and fruit to sell.

loans.use: To buy more fruit and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Sarin

texts.en:
Sarin M. is 37 years old and resides with her husband and three of her children in Batambong province. Three of her children are in school.

Sarin M. makes a living of US$4 of profit every day by selling fish at the market. She is also supported by her husband who works in construction building houses and also grows vegetables. He typically makes US$5 of profit per day.

Sarin M. would like to take out a loan of US$1,000 so that she can purchase more fish to sell at the market and also a motorbike for transportation.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell and to buy a motorbike

loans.name: Loung

texts.en:
Mrs. Loung L. A., age 27, and her husband, Kong Loung, 34 (he appears in the photo), live in their own small house with their two children in Kampong ChhnA. Province.

To earn a living, this couple sells cooking ingredients that they buy in bulk from the market at reasonable prices. Some of their clients are their nearby neighbors who buy their produce on credit for a few days. To satisfy their client needs, Long L. A. has applied for a loan to use as capital to buy a larger quantity of grocery items.

loans.use: To buy a larger quantity of grocery items

loans.name: Ouch

texts.en:
Ouch S., 65, is married with three children. She resides in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia with her husband and children. Her husband is a village chief, earning an income of US $10 per day. The family is also assisted by all of her children who are currently employed in a local garment factory, and another one is a teacher at a local primary school. They all help cover the household expenses.

To make a living, S. is engaged in selling clothes, earning an income of approximately US$3 per day. This is her third loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. She and her children are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of US$400 to purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Chong

texts.en:
Chong R. is 50 years old and lives in the Battambang province with her husband and three of her adult children.

Since 2005 she has sold Khmer food at the local market to earn approximately US$9 eveR. day. Her husband is too old to make a living so he stays at home. Chong is aided by her three children, of whom two are construction workers and one is a mechanic repairer.

Chong R. is asking for a loan of US$1000 so her son can open a mechanic shop and purchase mechanic’s tools for his business.

loans.use: Open a mechanic shop.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mrs. Mary T., 32, has been a tailor for over three years and her husband, Mr. Vibol Chan, 35, has been driving a motor Remoque for over one year. (A Remoque is a motorbike connected to a trailer at the back.)

They have been married since 1999 and have two sons who are in school. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number 5 about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mary has requested a loan one time already. She is now is asking for her second loan of US$500 to buy cloth and silk fabric from the market in Phnom Penh to continue operating her tailoring business.

loans.use: To purchase silk fabric and cloth for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Pun

texts.en:
Pun S. is 53 years old and lives in the Battambang province with her husband and three of her children.

She is a farmer who typically makes about US $2 in profit every day and her husband is a taxi driver who makes US $4 each day. This couple is also aided by two children, one a construction worker and the other a taxi driver.

Pun S. requests a loan of US $500 so she can purchase a hand tractor and a trailer to transport rice.

loans.use: To purchase a hand tractor.

loans.name: Teb

texts.en:
Teb P., 66, resides in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia with his wife and their 5 children.

To make a living Teb cuts hair for which he earns approximately US $2 per day. His wife rents part of their house to employees of a local garment factory for which she earns US $2 per day. The family is also assisted by two of their children who are currently employed as nurses. They all help to cover the household expenses.

Teb and his wife seek to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Teb is requesting a loan of US $200 to purchase more supplements to aid his barber shop. This is his second loan from Kiva partner CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy more supplements to aid his barber shop.

loans.name: Yang

texts.en:
Mr. Yang V. is 29 years old and a resident of Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. He and his wife have two children who attend school.

To earn a living Yang travels to work in construction. For another source of family income his wife works in the garment industry.

To make additional income Yang would like to borrow a Kiva loan which he will use to buy pig food and a piglet to begin raising pigs.

loans.use: To buy pig food and piglet to begin raising pigs.

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mr. Mom S., age 41, and his wife, Mrs. Nary Bun (pictured), age 37, live in a small village outside of Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1987 and have four children. Of their three sons, two are in school and the other one is still too young. Their daughter is a garment-factory worker.  
 
Mom has been a journalist for seven years. His wife stays at home and does housework. He is asking for his first loan of $400 to purchase a motorcycle for his children to ride to school.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for his children to ride to school.

loans.name: Tan

texts.en:
Tan C. is 30 years old and lives with her husband in the Takeo province. She is a good housewife who lives at home take care of her children and cook for the family members. Her husband is a construction worker who is able to make $4 of profit every day. This couple has two school-aged children. 

Tan C. plans to raise pigs to have additional income to help raise their standard of living. She needs a loan of $500 to raise pigs.

loans.use: Raise pigs

loans.name: Cicilia

texts.en:
Cicilia Sebit is currently in the business of selling clothes in the market and is requesting a loan to purchase more goods like shoes, jackets, etc., to sell.  Cicilia is 28 years old and married to a clerk. She has six children. Her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more goods like shoes, jackets, etc., to sell

loans.name: Keng

texts.en: Keng M. is 29 years old and lives with her husband and two young children in Takeo province. She is a professional weaver who is able to make a living wage of US$ 3 every day, while her husband is a farmer and makes US$ 2 per day. Keng M. is asking for a loan of US$ 1200. Her husband needs to invest in a new business. He wants to operate a moto-taxi, and so he needs this loan to purchase a motorbike.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Phally

texts.en:
Miss Phally N., 35 (on the left), is single and lives with her father and sister and brother along National Road Number One about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Phally has been a farmer for about 2 years. She hopes to increase the yield of her vegetables, so she is applying for her first loan of US$ 300 in order to purchase fertilizer to put on her vegetable farm.

loans.use: To use for growing vegetables

loans.name: Un

texts.en:
Un Y. is a 45-year-old widowed villager who lives in Kampong Chhnang province. She is the mother of four children; two are employed, one works driving a taxi and another one is a garment worker. Her husband died of senility years ago. Although a widow, she is a determined woman who tries to earn money from making clay stoves. She waits till she has a lot of stoves before selling to her customers.

Recently, her stock of the raw materials she needs has run out. Therefore, Un Y. is applying for a loan in order to purchase clay to make stoves for sale.

loans.use: To purchase clay to make stoves for sale

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine S. is engaged in vegetables, ice cream and fishball vending. Her husband named Noli is also engaged in the same business. Josephine use a motorcycle in selling her products while her husband uses a bicycle. The couple is blessed with six children who are all studying.

Josephine wishes to have a bigger income so as to continue sending her children to school. Through their businesses she and her husband believe that nothing is impossible, thus they really want those to progress. With that purpose in mind, Josephine is requesting a loan from KIVA lenders to help them in maintaining their businesses with the amount of Php 5,000 that she would like to borrow. She prays that KIVA lenders will be generous enough to help her.

loans.use: additional capital for her business

loans.name: Say

texts.en: Say L. is 35 years old and lives with her husband and three young children in Takeo province. She is a professional weaver who is able to make a living of US$ 3 every day, while her husband is a recycler and also makes US$ 3 per day. Say L. is asking for a loan of US$ 800 which she needs to purchase more silk to expand her business.

loans.use: materials for weaving

loans.name: Sar

texts.en: Sar S. is 28 years old and lives with her two young children and her elderly parents in Takeo province. She is a professional weaver who is able to make of US$ 3 every day. Sar S. is asking for a loan of US$ 800 to purchase more silk so she can weave products to sell at the local market.

loans.use: Weaving silk dresses

loans.name: Sin

texts.en: Sin N. is 55 years old and lives with her husband and four of her children in Takeo province. Since 1999, she has been working as a professional weaver who is able to make a living of US$ 3 every day, while her husband is a farmer and makes US$ 2 per day. Sin N. is asking for a loan of US$ 700 which her husband needs to purchase cows to assist him in his farm work.

loans.use: To purchase cows to work in the fields with her husband

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Saroeun P., 40, is widow with three children: one son and two daughters. The eldest daughter is garment factory worker and another one is in school. They are living along National Road Number One approximately 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Saroeun has been selling vegetables for about 10 years. She buys them from farmers in her village for resale in Phnom Penh market. Also, the house where she lives is broken down in some parts so she decided to repair it, but she doesn’t have money to pay for repairing costs.

Hence she is asking for her first loan of US$ 300 to pay for her house repairs.

loans.use: To pay for her house repairs

loans.name: Hul

texts.en:
Hul T. is 47 years old and a resident of Kompong Chhnang Province where she has owned a plot of land since 1979. She grows rice, which she plants twice a year. She is widowed and the mother of two children, both of whom are employed in a garment factory.

Hul T. works hard at her business activities every day and never wastes time so that she can support her family. Hul T. faces difficulty with her living condition because the roof of her house is falling down; thus, she applies for a loan to pay the cost of repairing the roof.

loans.use: To pay the cost of repairing her roof

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
Linda K. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to buy more bags of charcoal to sell. Linda is 38 years old and is married to a husband who is a teacher. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business of selling charcoal.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: buy more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Sar

texts.en: Sar U. is 62 years old and lives with her husband and three of her children in the Takeo province. Since 1999, she has been working as a professional weaver, making $3 (US) every day, while her husband is a farmer who makes $2 (US) per day. She is asking for a loan of $700 (US), which she will use to purchase more silk to make clothes to sell at the local market.

loans.use: to purchase silk to make clothes

loans.name: Sambath

texts.en:
Mrs. Sambath T., 27, and her husband, Mr. Sopha Sun, 29, have been married since 2000, and have one daughter who is in school. They live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. Her husband is pictured in the photo.

Sambath has been a silk weaver for 9 years, a skill she learned from her sister in-law. She sells her finished product to a middleman in the village where she lives, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh market. Her husband is a construction worker. He works in his village. 

Sambath has asked for a loan from Kiva through Maxima once before. She is now requesting another loan of $150 to purchase silk materials to maintain her weaving business.

loans.use: to purchase silk materials to maintain her weaving business

loans.name: Kol

texts.en: Kol C., 35, lives in the Takeo province with her husband and two of her children. She is a garment factory worker who is able to make a living of US $3.80 each day.  Her husband is a blacksmith and makes US $8 per day. This couple also support one child, who is a hairdresser and makes US $3 a day. Kol C. would like to take out a loan of US $600 on behalf of her daughter, who wants to open a hairdresser shop.

loans.use: to open a hairdresser shop

loans.name: Choijilsuren

texts.en:
Choijilsuren N. is 38 years old and lives with her husband and 3-year-old child in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Her husband is self-employed and works as carpenter in their town. Their only child will soon start kindergarten. 

N. operates a hair and beauty salon in her town along with several of her friends who are beauticians and hairdressers. They share the rent of the room in which they operate their business. N. started the salon in 1998 with a working capital of 200,000 tugrugs (~140 USD). The business has grown steadily over the years and is now a popular salon in the area. Today, her working capital exceeds 500,000 tugrugs (~350 USD).  While her cooperation with her friends has proven to be successful, N. dreams of being on her own. She says, "I would like to open my own beauty and hair salon in the future." She is requesting a 700,000 tugrug (~490 USD) loan to purchase beauty products for her business. 			

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

loans.use: to purchase beauty products for her business

loans.name: Nhel

texts.en: Nhel N. is a 42 year old fruit seller in the Takeo province. Her business has been around for about eight years and she makes US $5 every day. Her husband is a moto-taxi driver and is able to make US $5 per day as well. Selling fruit has been a difficult business, as there is high inflation and weather conditions that have not been conducive to a good growing season. Nhel is asking for a loan of US $750 to make two investments: she would like to use US $500 to help her husband purchase a trailer, and put the remaining US $250 into her own fruit business, increasing her stock of fruit to sell. She sees these investments as opportunities to increase her daily income.

loans.use: to purchase a trailer for her husband and reinvest in her fruit business

loans.name: Sinat

texts.en:
Mrs. Sinat S., 34 has been married to Mr. Voeun Nhoem, 33, since 2006. They have a young son. The couple lives in a small village off of National Road Number 2 about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. Sinat’s old mother also lives with the family.

Sinat has been a silk weaver for more than 5 years, while her husband has been a construction worker for 2 years.

Because silk weaving is the business that Sinat has run for long time and it’s her main source of income, she is asking for a loan of US$150 to purchase silk materials (raw silk) to continue her business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for her silk  weaving business.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Chea S. is a married mother, 52 years old, who resides in Kampong Chhnang province.

To make a living Chea S. sells vegetables and some meats in the local market where she earns an average of $3 each day. She buys in bulk on credit from her supplier. Normally she starts selling her items in the morning and finishes in the late afternoon with much income.

Chea S. wants to buy a bicycle for her child to ride to school but her money is not enough to buy one. Therefore she would like a loan from Kiva through HKL to buy a bicycle. She will use the rest of the loan to increase her business capital.

loans.use: To buy a bicycle and to increase her business capital.

loans.name: Tim

texts.en:
Tim P., 30, is married with two young children living at home in the Takeo province.

Tim raises pigs and grows rice, typically making US $2 each day. Her husband, Chorn Chhan, typically makes about US $5 each day as a recycler.

Tim would like a loan of US $450 for a new investment. She will use this loan to purchase a sugar cane cart.

loans.use: To buy a cart to sell sugar cane juice.

loans.name: Long

texts.en:
Long P. is a 48-year-old farmer who lives in Kampong Chhnang province. She is married to Mr. Bunthoeun, age 39, who works with her in the farming business.

This couple owns a cultivating machine that they use for their farming. In addition, they use their machine to plow a nearby farmer’s farmland for profit.

Unfortunately the machine has often broken down during the plowing process.

Because of this problem, Long P. would like a loan to purchase spare parts in order to replace a part of the cultivating machine.

Long P. was not available on this day so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for their cultivating machine.

loans.name: Samphors

texts.en:
Mrs. Samphors S., age 28, is a widow with a young son. She lives with her old father in a suburb about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

She has been a garment factory worker since 1998.

Samphors wants to expand her house’s shape so it will be better for her family to live in. She is asking for her first loan of $700 to put additional space on her house.

loans.use: To put additional space on her house.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a large stock of artificial flowers

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann M. is from San Jose Norte 2, Mallig Isabela. She is married to Artemeo M.. They are both 32 years old and have two children. The elder is a boy and he is already studying. The younger one is 1 year old. 

Mary Ann is requesting the amount of 50,000 Philippine pesos from Kiva lenders for additional capital to maintain and improve her store. She started her business selling junk foods in her general store. While she is reaching years in her business, she also achieved improvement in her business and became a dealer of soft drinks in their village. At present, she is selling feed for hogs, liquefied petroleum gas, slippers and other items that are important to their locality for daily consumption.

Her husband accompanied her in delivering the products and also in purchasing goods in the market for their store to minimize expenses. Her husband is the one who will drive their motorcycle and use it for their business. They have also improved their house and have an extension of their kitchen from their income. According to this couple, they have about Php 3,000 weekly net income and they continuously revolve it to the other business. 

One of the dreams of Mary Ann is to improve her business so that someday it will become a grocery shop to help people within their village.

loans.use: Additional capital to maintain and improve her store business

location.town: San Jose Norte II, Mallig, Isabela

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji C. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs in a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase other goods like sodas, water, juice, etc to sell.  Keji is 36 years old and is married to a soldier. She has six children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a big shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more goods like sodas, water, juice etc to sell

loans.name: Can Wange Pe Dima Caroline Group

texts.en: D. Caroline is representing her group. She is a business lady, 22 years old and married with three children. Two of her children go to school. She sells used clothes, which she has been doing for over three years. She is requesting a loan to purchase more stock of used clothes, especially for the Christmas season because the profits are going to be so high. She hopes to increase her capital. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to educate her children and purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothes

loans.name: Rowel

texts.en:
Rowel R. is engaged in the motorcycle transport business while his wife is an Overseas Filipino Worker. At the age of 34, Rowel now has one child named Ram Ain who is only five years old. The main reason the couple is really working hard is to save for the education of their child. They know that education is really important for a better future.

In this regard, Rowel wants to borrow a loan from ASKI of PHP 5,000 for the maintenance of his passenger motorcycle. He shared that in this type of business, customer service and kindness is very important. One must respect the passengers to have more customers, which results in a bigger income. Rowel only hopes that lenders will approve his loan.

loans.use: To maintain his motorcycle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more stock in  bulk

loans.name: Lay

texts.en: Lay K., 57, is married and lives with her six children in the Takeo province. She works in a grocery store, making around US$1.30 each day. Her husband works as a moto-taxi driver. Her husband makes about US$2.60 each day. Food prices have soared in the past year as inflation has gotten out of control in Cambodia. Unfavorable climate conditions have also played a factor in making the price of rice very high. Lay K. is asking for a loan of US$1100 for her husband to purchase a trailer and a motorbike to run a moto-taxi business.

loans.use: To buy a trailer and a motorbike

loans.name: Sreymom

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreymom M., 33 and her husband, Mr. Try Kong, 36, have been married since 1996 and have three children: two daughters and one son. The eldest daughter is a garment factory worker and the other two attend school. The family is living in a small village along National Road Number 2 about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Sreymom has been a construction worker in her village for three years, while her husband has been a working in the administrative headquarters of the province for 10 years. Some part of her house has broken down and that’s why she is asking for her first loan of $500 to repair her house.  She will make a staircase and repair the wall of the house.

loans.use: To repair her house

loans.name: Can Wange Pe Auma Edisa Group

texts.en: A. Edisa is the president of her group. She is a married business lady, 36 years of age, who is blessed with six children. Three of the children go to school. She has had a cereal business (maize flour) for over 10 years. She is requesting a loan to purchase maize and grind it into maize flour ready for sale. She is a creative and hardworking business lady whose dream is to educate her children and purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase more maize

loans.name: Gny

texts.en: Gny R., 32, is married and lives with her four children in the Takeo province. She stays at home making cowbells and selling them at the local market to earn less than US$1 per day. Her husband is a middleman who sells motorbikes. He typically makes about US$16 in revenue each day. One of her children also works. Gny R. would like to take out a loan of US$1200. Her husband needs to purchase a motorbike to resell.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to resell.

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Mr. Kong S. is a widower caring for two teenage children. Kong S. is currently a local carpenter who makes tables, chairs, and cupboards for sale. He sells furniture to the customer after he finishes making it. Almost all of his clients need to wait a few weeks. Kong S. has operated his business for a long time, but he still needs some materials.  Kong S. is pursuing a loan to purchase extra carpentry materials to better supply the good service he provides.

loans.use: To purchase extra carpentry materials

loans.name: Dhan

texts.en:
Due to hardships and difficulties in life, Dhan R. did not pursue his studies in college. He works as a conductor for one of the noble families in Solano. For five years, he has been married to Cherry Ann. They are gifted with two children namely, Diether Harry R. and Princess Dhanery R.. They live peacefully in a village located at Brgy. Quirino, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. Being parents, they have the responsibility to send their children to school and give them a better future. 
	Despite the hardships and difficulties in life, they are striving hard to earn an income and to support the financial needs of their children in school. His wife chose to work as an Overseas Factory Worker in Bierut, Lebanon while Dhan is busy doing his work as a conductor. After two years, his wife bought a jeepney for them which they used to earn income. For the maintenance of their jeepney, Dhan is applying for a loan amounting to Php5,000.00 from the KIVA lenders. He hopes that with this financial assistance, he can continuously use his jeepney to earn a living and support the schooling of their children. Through their patience and sacrifices, he can earn a net income of P 6,000.00 a month, which he used to acquire their daily needs and finance the schooling of their children.

loans.use: Additional capital for the maintenance of his jeepney

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Saor

texts.en: Saor V. is 48 years old and lives with his wife in Takeo province. He is a motor-taxi driver who makes about $2.60 USD of profit every day, while his wife stays at home making and selling cow bells for less than $1 USD per day. The couple has two children who are employed as construction workers. Saor V. would like a loan of $800 USD to purchase a motorbike to operate a motor-taxi business. (Saor V. is pictured with his wife at home.)

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a 29-year-old single mother with an 8-year-old son. For the last four years, she has run a business supplying wrapping paper, plastics, and old newspaper. Her customers include businesses like butcheries, retail shops, and take-away food kiosks. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to purchase more stock to deliver direct to wholesalers.

Rose describes herself as very ambitious and hardworking and says that since joining Kiva partner Faulu she has become more knowledgeable about business matters and a better saver. In the future, she hopes to buy a pick-up truck to deliver her products to wholesalers in Kericho and bring food items in return. She would also like to build a flat to rent out for extra income.

About Faulu Kenya
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To purchase stock

loans.name: Alona

texts.en:
Alona is a hog raiser in the village of Sto. Niño, San Agustin. She would like to renovate her pigs' pen and buy additional feed supply for her pigs. However, the income she is earning is not enough, so she wants to borrow a loan form Kiva lenders amounting to Php4,000. With that amount she knows that the renovation of her pigs' pen and the purchase of additional feed for her animals will become reality.

Alona is married to Wilmer, who is a farmer. They are blessed with six children: Wilson-21 years old, Wojay-19 years old, Wilmer Jr.-15 years old, Wilma-14 years old, Whiny-ten years old, and Windy-one year old. Alona and Wilmer are praying to be able to provide for the needs of their children through the business they manage.

loans.use: Additional capital for the renovation of her pigs' pen and to buy feed

loans.name: Can Wange Pe Alanyo Jenniffer Group

texts.en: A. Jenniffer is the representative of this loan group. She is married with four children, three of whom go to school. For the past six years Jenniffer has had a business selling smoked fish. She is requesting a loan to add capital into her business by purchasing fish to sell direct to customers and also in the market place. She is a promising businesswoman whose dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To add capital into her business by purchasing fish for resale

loans.name: Nen

texts.en: Nen K., 37, is married and lives with her five children in Takeo province. She stays at home making and selling cow bells to sell in the local market, and earns less than $1 USD per day. Her husband is a middle man who sells motorbikes, and also a motor-taxi driver. He typically makes about $5 USD per day. Nen K. would like a loan of $700 USD for her husband to replace his old motorbike.

loans.use: To replace an old motorbike

loans.name: Dorjgotov

texts.en:
Dorjgotov Y. is 22 years old and lives with her parents in Bayanhongor province in central Mongolia. She and her parents live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent.

Y. operates a small cafe in her town, which she started in early 2009. Previously, she worked at her sister's cafe, a noodle factory and a dairy trade business. In these previous jobs, Y. gained much business knowledge and experience in food-related businesses, which enabled her to start her cafe.

Her business has progressed very quickly in its first year of operation and she is already planning to expand her building. Y. is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase a new window and door for her cafe building and coal to heat the building this winter.

About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

loans.use: To purchase a new window and door for her cafe and coal to heat the building this winter

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en:
