Mary Grace G. is from the village of Batangan, Valencia City. She is 38 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Grace owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Mary Grace has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Mary Grace joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Grace is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel G. is 21 years old and married to a community leader. She has two children who both go to school. G. is currently in the business of selling fish, onions and tomatoes, and is requesting a loan to buy more items, such as beans and rice, for resale. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a large retail shop.

About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase other food items to sell

loans.name: Khann

texts.en:
Khann S., 28, is a farmer living in Takeo province with her husband and child. She typically makes $1 USD each day and her husband makes about $8 USD in revenue working in a motor-taxi business.

The climate conditions for farming have been unfavorable in Cambodia this past year and this has caused food prices to soar. Inflation has also been out of control, and this has turned into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Khann S. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of $600 USD for her husband to replace an old and unreliable motorbike.

loans.use: To replace an old and unreliable motorbike

loans.name: Can Wange Pe Akello Margaret Group

texts.en:
A. Margaret is 39 years old and blessed with four children, all of whom are in school. She also looks after three dependents, who are also schooling.

Margaret deals in produce such as beans and groundnuts. She is requesting a loan to purchase more produce in order to increase her stock. She wishes to purchase six bags of each produce (beans, groundnuts, etc.). Margaret is an active businesswoman whose dream is to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase more produce (beans, groundnuts, etc.) in order to increase her stock

loans.name: Srun

texts.en:
Srun N. is 57 years old and lives with her husband in Takeo province. The couple has two children, one of whom is a student and the other of whom is a wedding chef.

Since 1999 Srun N. has been raising pigs and making rice wine to earn a living. She is able to make about $3.70 USD of profit each day. Her husband is a rice miller and makes $1 USD per day. Srun N. would like to take out a loan of $1000 USD for her husband to purchase rice and take off the husk with the intention of reselling the rice and turning over a profit. She is confident that this will be a good business venture, and sees it as a tool to increase her income and raise her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase rice to take off the husk and resell

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mao P., 54, is a widow and mother. Mao P. currently owns a small kiosk inside the market where she sells some snack foods for breakfast. She is also a good homemaker who cares for two children and holds a daily routine as well. One of her children is married and the other one is single, and they are employed in different occupations.

Mao P. has been building her new house for months but the new house is still not completed. Due to her lack of money, Mao P. decided to ask for a loan from Kiva’s partner HLK to be used to finish building her house.

loans.use: To be used to finish building her house

loans.name: Florentina

texts.en:
Florentina D. is already 43 years old and married to Constancio, who works as a carpenter. “Prayer accompanied by hard work” is Florentina's guiding principle . The couple together with their children are happily living in the village of Quezon, San Isidro. Their children are: Jonathan-24 years old, college undergraduate; Jerwin-22 years old; and Jayson-18 years old, who is a high school graduate.

Florentina says that through her business she tries to support her family. But due to the high cost of commodities, the income that she generates from her general store is insufficient for their daily needs, thus she is requesting a loan of Php 5,000, allowing her to make the general store progressive. This amount will serve as a big help in expanding her business and fulfilling her dreams as well.

loans.use: additional capital for business improvement

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock in bulk for her business

loans.name: Sokheang

texts.en: Mrs. Sokheang C. is a villager in Preak Tanop village in Kandal province. She and her husband are fish breeders. Since this business is going well, Mrs. Sokheang C. wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more fish for breeding. Mrs. Sokheang C. has six children, three of whom work in a garment factory while the others attend the local school. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more fish for breeding.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Isidra

texts.en:
Isidra G. is from the village of Colonia, Valencia City. She is 50 years old, married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Isidra owns and operates a business venture in the food sector running a bakery shop. The main source of income for the business comes from baking and selling bread in the local community. Isidra has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Isidra joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Isidra is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her bakery business

loans.name: Sabrina

texts.en:
Sabrina Q. is from the village of Clarin, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 37 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Sabrina owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector selling fish. The main source of income for the business comes from raising fish for sale. Sabrina has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Sabrina joined Kiva partner GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from GDMPC. This loan was used to purchase fish for sale. Sabrina is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase fish for sale. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees.

About GDMPC
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fish for sale

loans.name: Nary

texts.en:
Mrs. Nary R. is a farmer who lives in Preak Tanop village in Kandal province. In her farming, she now faces a small problem because she does not have enough money to buy rice seed to cultivate rice. Thus, Mrs. Nary R. decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed for her purpose and she would use the rest of the money to buy a water pump to water her crop.

Mrs. Nary R.’s husband, Mr. Seng Sokhom, is also a farmer who helps his wife with the business. Mrs. Nary R. has a child who is too young to work or study because the child is only three years old. Her husband is shown on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and a water pump

loans.name: Kade

texts.en:
Kade A. is 30 years old and married to a police officer. She has six children, all of whom go to school. Kade is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste and is requesting a loan to buy more items to sell, such as beans, rice, posho (a cornmeal product), etc. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to expand her business and open a shop.

About BRAC Southern Sudan
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more items, such as beans, rice, and posho

loans.name: Namjilsuren

texts.en:
Namjilsuren E. is 50 years old and lives with her husband and son in Arhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her son, Narangerel, is 20 years old and a university student.

E. operates a firewood-selling business in her town. She purchases wood from various suppliers throughout her province and transports it to Ulaanbaatar, the largest city and capital of Mongolia, to sell.

E. started her business in 2008 with capital of 1,000,000 MNT. She has made good progress with her business in her first year of operation, and continues to gain much experience. In just one year, she has doubled her working capital to a level exceeding 2,000,000 MNT. She hopes to continue to increase her earnings in the future and says, "I work hard so that I can pay tuition for my son." She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more wood to sell.

About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

loans.use: To purchase more wood to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Sokunthea San Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Fourteen people who live in Koh Kaev Kraom village in Kandal province make up this village bank loan and they will use the loan which they obtain for different purposes. Mrs. Sokunthea S. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members.

Mrs. Sokunthea S. owns a small grocery in the village. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries for her business.

Mrs. Sokunthea S.’s husband, Mr. Huon Heat, helps his wife with the current business. Mrs. Sokunthea S. has two children who are both attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for her business

loans.name: Jamba

texts.en:
Jamba O. is 27 years old and lives with his wife and four children in Dornogobi province in southern Mongolia. He and his family live in their own house. His eldest son and daughter, aged 17 and 10, currently attend a local secondary school, and his youngest son and daughter, aged 6 and 4, will soon start school. O.'s wife, Otgonbayar, supports the family by managing their small grocery store next to their house.

O. operates a taxi service in his town. He injured his leg when he was 16 years old and has had an artificial leg ever since. It makes his work difficult, but he works hard to support his family. O. started driving a taxi in 2002 and has been quite successful. His earnings have allowed him to build the shop and open the grocery business for his wife.

For the future, the family is very focused on growing both of their businesses. They hope to expand the product variety at the grocery shop to attract new customers. O. is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase groceries such as flour, rice and candies to sell at the grocery shop.

In the picture, O. is shown next to the car he uses for his taxi service.

About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

loans.use: To purchase groceries such as flour, rice and candies

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina G. is from the village of Batangan, Valencia City. She is 38 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Gina owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Gina has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Gina joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase an additional stock of ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth A.'s main source of income comes from planting and harvesting vegetables for sale. She is 50 years old, married and has three school-age children. They are from the village of Lucsoon, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. Elizabeth has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2007, Elizabeth joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Elizabeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from GDMPC. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be her sixth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Mrs. Thai Chem Village Bank Group

texts.en: The village bank loan, which consists of fourteen people, is located in Koh Kaev Kraom village in Kandal province. All the members will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Thai C. is the village bank president, as selected by the members. She is a rice seller in the local village. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it. She decided to ask for a loan to buy more rice to re-sell. She is a widow with four children, one of whom is a laborer while the others are married and live separately.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy more rice to re-sell.

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
Nelly D. P. is from the village of Sinayawan. Valencia, Bukidnon. She is 35 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children.

Nelly owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products and sometimes  they sell fish using improvised motorcycle design for fish peddling in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Nelly joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Nelly has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell.

Nelly is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 4th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 


About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock of traditional African cloth

loans.name: Soem

texts.en:
Soem K. is 59 years old and a resident of Pursat Province, Cambodia. She earns a living as a tailor, providing her service to neighbors, sewing both traditional clothes and modern clothes. On the other hand, Soem K. and her husband always cultivate rice and raise pigs as well. From these businesses, Soem K. can earn an average of US$6 per day.

Soem K. is a married woman blessed with seven children, three of whom are employed in various jobs and the remainder are students.

Soem K. doesn't have her own vehicle, so she always faces difficulties with her traveling needs. Because of this obstacle, she is applying for a loan to buy a used motorcycle to ride.

loans.use: To buy a used motorcycle to ride

loans.name: Flordelisa

texts.en: Flordelisa B. is from the village of Laligan, Valencia City. She is 43 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Flordelisa owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Flordelisa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Flordelisa is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 5th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Mrs. Ry Seam Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. Ry S. is a village bank president, as selected by thirteen people in Kaev Kraom village, in Kandal province. Mrs. Ry S. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice, to earn a living. In this farming, she faces a small problem because she does not have enough money to buy fertilizers for her fields, to make the crops more productive. Her husband, Mr. Reoung Sameth, is a teacher who makes a small salary to support the family. Mrs. Ry S. has four children who are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to support the field to make the crop more productive.

loans.name: Bayan

texts.en:
Bayan T. lives with her husband and two children in a house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her son, age 25, currently attends university and her daughter, age 19, will soon graduate from secondary school. T.'s husband, Nanjil, supports the family by using their car as a taxi. T. operates a consumer-goods selling business at a local market in the city. Currently her business is good, and she rents two stalls at which she sells her products. Her two children are very supportive and help their family when they can. Her daughter helps her mother at the market in her spare time, and her son carefully raises fish to be sold as pets. T. works hard to grow her business and hopes to expand in the near future. She is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug loan to import products from China to sell. About XacBank:
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

loans.use: To import products from China to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Pheang Uon Group

texts.en: Mrs. Pheang U. is a group leader of four who all live in Ta Ou Kang Cheung village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land upon which she cultivates rice. She is also a pig breeder. Now she is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer to support the field and to buy piglets for breeding. She hopes to increase her income and to improve the family’s living conditions with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Ngaet Hon, helps her in the business. Mrs. Pheang U. is the mother of two children, one of whom is a construction worker while the other is studying at the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to support the field and to buy piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Namsraijav

texts.en:
Namsraijav T. is 24 years old and lives with her husband and 2-year-old son in Tuv province in central Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian tent home. Her husband, Enkhbayar, owns a microbus and earns money by transporting people. T. operates a grocery trading business at the local market in her town. She started her grocery service in 2008 and has quickly made good progress with her business. Her earnings have enabled her to purchase a refrigerator for her business and a computer for her family. T. is very hardworking and is focused on operating an honest business. She says, "I will work hard to pay the bank loan on time and I will use it to grow my business." She is requesting a loan in the amount of 1,600,000 tugrug (~1120 USD) to purchase a large amount of flour for her grocery trading business.

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of flour for her grocery trading business.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary T. is married and has five dependants. She has received education up to the senior high level.  Mary sells smoked fish at Elmina seashore, which she has been doing since 1990. Her husband is a fisherman. Mary uses her income to support the husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.  Mary will use the loan to buy more fresh fish to smoke and fire wood for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to save to build her own house and to reinvest.

To smoke her fish, she goes to the seashore to buy fresh fish from the fishermen. She comes home with the fish, cleans or dresses them and drains the water that comes about as a result of washing the fish. She prepares her traditionally made oven with firewood to smoke her fish for sale.

loans.use: To buy more fresh fish to smoke and fire wood for sale.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Mrs. C. C. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Srey Hen, helps her. Although they work hard, they still do not earn enough money to support the family. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. C. C. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She hopes to improve their living conditions after she sells this cow.

Mrs. C. C. is a villager in Prey Meas village in Takeo province. She is the mother of a child who is attending the local school. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Kambua

texts.en:
Kambua is a 36 year-old, married mother of three children. She has been running a business as a butcher, in Nairobi, for three years. Kambua was able to open the butcher business thanks to a loan from Faulu. She is now requesting a loan of KES 60,000 to renovate the business, purchase a weighing machine, and open a fashion and design shop in the market. She describes herself as stable and hopes to open another butcher shop in the future.

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Renovate business & to purchase a weighing machine.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma C. is from the village of Batangan, Valencia City. She is 38 years old. Gemma is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Gemma raises ducks to lay eggs and sells the eggs for balot and penoy, a traditional nutritious Filipino food made from duck eggs. Gemma has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Gemma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Gemma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Gemma is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to expand the shelter for her livestock. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Gemma from HSPFI. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand shelter for livestock.

loans.name: Torn

texts.en:
Mr. Torn N. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this, he is a pig breeder. Since these two businesses are going well, he wants to expand them, so he decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers to support the field. He will use the rest of the loan to buy piglets and pig feed.

Mr. Torn N. is a villager in Srae Vong village in Takeo province. His wife, Mrs. Lach Keourn, helps him with the business. They have three children: one is working in a garment factory while the others are in school. His wife is shown on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Men

texts.en: The woman in the photograph is Men T., age 38. She lives in the province of Pursat, which is the best territory for farming. Men T. has two young children who attend school and depend on her care. Men T. owns a medium farm that she inherited from her grandmother. She grows various crops on her land. Another source of family income comes from her husband's battery charging business. From this charging service, Men T.'s husband can generate a good income. Men T. is taking out her loan to buy another machine for battery charging in order to satisfy their customer’s needs.

loans.use: To buy a battery charging machine

loans.name: Vuthy

texts.en:
Mr. Vuthy C. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this, he is a pig breeder. Since this business is going well, he wants to expand it, so he decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets and feed.

Mr. Vuthy C. lives in Srae Nong village in Takeo province. His wife, Mrs. Nao Srey Neang, is a farmer. He is the father of a young child who is 6 months old. His wife is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and feed

loans.name: Violet

texts.en:
Violet is 40 years old and married with four children. She has run an embroidery business in Nairobi for two years, creating tablecloths, and ladies clothes. She describes her business as stable and having a pleasant environment. She is requesting a loan for KES 50,000 to buy a Janome machine and a Singer machine. In the future, she hopes to also purchase a printer and to build a rental home, as she expands her business.

About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To buy Janome and Singer machines.

loans.name: Ma. Luz

texts.en:
Ma Luz C. is from the village of Sinayawan, Valencia Bukidnon. She is 41 years old. Ma Luz is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Ma Luz raises goats for sale. Ma. Luz has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Ma Luz joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Ma Luz has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise for resale. Ma Luz is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Ma Luz from HSPFI. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Mrs. Touch Long Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Touch L. is the group leader of six people who all live in Hang Heng village in Takeo province.

Mrs. Touch L. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Heng Mao, is a construction worker. Since his workplace is far from home and he usually spends a lot of money on transportation, Mrs. Touch L. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her husband to use to go to work.

Mrs. Touch L. is the mother of three children, one of whom is working in a small company while the others are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband to drive to work

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase the quantity and range of stock for her business.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is 24 years old and married with two children, a son and a daughter. She has run Glory Chemist for three years. Her business is located at a strategic point in her neighborhood and she is able to employ one person. She is requesting a loan for KES 20,000 to purchase a computer for data entry.

Christine believes that she has the potential to raise herself to a higher standard of living and, from Faulu, she says she has learnt the importance of saving. Her dream is to open a clinic.

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To buy a computer.

loans.name: Touch

texts.en: Mr. S. is 40 years old and a resident of the Pursat province, Cambodia. To earn a living, S. sells firewood that he harvests, from the forest. He has been running his business since 2000, and is typically earning an average of $3 per day. S. is married with three children who are dependent on him and they are also going to school. His wife stays at home to care for the children and also sells a few groceries for a profit. S. is applying for a loan as capital to purchase a water buffalo to connect with a cart to serve as his wood harvesting transportation.

loans.use: To purchase a water buffalo for wood transportation.

loans.name: Moeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Moeun R. lives in Saen Bon village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns three hectare fields (7.5 acres) on which she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Chuon Von, is a construction worker who can make a small income to support the family.

Even thought they try to work hard, they still earn less income than is needed to support their household. Thus, Mrs. Moeun R. decided to ask for a loan to buy one more cow for her cattle-breeding business.

Mrs. Moeun R. is the mother of six children, three of whom are working in a garment factory while another is a construction worker and the other two are attending the local school. Her husband is shown on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy one more cow for her cattle-breeding business

loans.name: Lita

texts.en:
Lita F. owns and operates a clothing business, buying and selling ready-to-wear items in her community. She is 46 years old and married. She is from the village of Batangan, Valencia City. Lita has been in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2009, Lita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Lita is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding a clothing business

loans.name: Sophea

texts.en: Mrs. Sophea T. was born in 1968 and she now lives in Sla village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Heam Samnang, helps her with the farming. Although they try to work hard, they still do not earn enough income to support their household. Thus, Mrs. Sophea T. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. All her children are married and living separately. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Luvsandash

texts.en:
Luvsandash B. is 53 years old and lives with his wife in Tuv province in central Mongolia. He and his wife live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. B. operates a felt-making business in his town with the help of his wife. He has worked as a herder for most of his life and started producing felt in 2007 as a way to increase his income. When he started, he used tools and equipment that he rented from a friend to produce felt. However, his recent success and earnings have enabled him to purchase his own tools and equipment. Today, he produces on average 6-8 pieces of felt per day. B. has found much success producing felt and has many customers that demand his high quality product. For the future, he dreams of one day opening a felt-production factory. He is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase new tools and wool to make felt. About XacBank:
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

loans.use: To purchase new tools and wool to make felt

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha F.'s main source of income comes from selling used bags and clothing locally known as "ukay-ukay" in her community. She is 50 years old, married and has two adult children. She is from the village of Colonia, Valencia City. Editha has been in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2009, Editha joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Editha is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mrs. Mom S. is a villager in Prey Meas village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who has a 2 hectare field to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Duong Chhum, is a village chief.

Since the work place is far from their house, Mrs. Mom S. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her husband to travel to work in order to reduce the distances. Mrs. Mom S. has four children, one of whom is working in a garment factory while the others are attending the local school. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband to travel to work.

loans.name: Zundui

texts.en:
D. is 39 years old and lives with her aunt and two sons in the Uvurkhangai province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Both of her sons, ages 18 and 16, attend a local high school. Her aunt stays at home and Daariima supports the entire family by operating a clothes-making business. 

She began her business in 2003 after working as a dressmaker for several years. At first, she only had one sewing machine and made clothes according to her customers’ specifications. Now she owns many different sewing machines and designs and sews the clothing according to her own tastes. Because of her beautiful designs and the quality craftsmanship of the clothes, Daariima has a large, loyal customer base. She says, “All I want is to grow my business in order to be able to pay my sons’ tuition so that they can have the best education possible.” D. is requesting a 4,200,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase a large amount of fabrics, materials, and tools for her business.	

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest micro-finance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of fabrics, materials, and tools for her business
